123.  An internal Uber team or group was formed with the name “WC UberWAV Strike 
 
Team.” 
 
124.  Despite knowing that making its service accessible is reasonable and required, Uber 
has prioritized its focus on other business interests.  
125.  For example, according to an electronic communication on the “WC UberWAV 
Strike Team”, on what is believed to be dated November 16, 2015, Christopher Ballard of Uber 
stated “Given all of the other issues we’re dealing with during this regulatory session, it appears 
that WAV will be addressed next year. I’ll address the group if this thinking changes.” 
126.  Upon information and belief, Mr. Ballard was discussing Uber’s WAV service 
generally.  
127.  Despite saying that WAV would be addressed “next year,” almost three years later 
WAV service is still not available in Jackson.  
128.  Indeed, on what is believed to be August 5, 2016, Julia Winkler Jacobson of Uber 
sent  out  an  email  stating: “WAV is  consistently unreliable, there’s no standardized launch 
approach across cities.” 
 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 25 of 33
 
1  ASSIST:  pivot  to  proactive  outreach  with  informational  materials  to  ALL  drivers; 
2  discontinued city-by-city launches 
3 
WAV: fixed percentage of gross booking dedicated to WAV in cities completing 100K 
4 
trips / week” 
5 
1
6 
7 
 
8 
F.  Uber is Obligated to Provide an Equivalent Level of Service to Individuals who 
9  Use Wheelchairs. 
10  131.  From approximately 2015 until January 30, 2018 Uber operated in various markets 
11 
in conjunction with a subsidiary company known as Xchange Leasing, LLC.  
12 
132.  Through this company, Uber worked with drivers to help said individuals obtain a 
13 
new vehicle.  
14 
133.  In response to a request for production of documents asking Uber to provide “Any 
15 
documents showing the range of vehicles which Xchange Leasing, LLC has entered into leading 
16 
agreement with drivers since October 1, 2015.” In response, Uber produced a document, attached 
17 
as  Exhibit  “G”,  which  shows  that  Xchange  Leasing  entered  into  leasing  agreements  with 
18 
approximately 130 “new vans.” 
19 
134.  These new vans were leased in the following states: Virginia, Texas, Pennsylvania, 
20 
Illinois, and Maryland. 
21 
22  135.  By having new vans in its transportation system, Uber triggered the requirements 
23  of 49 C.F.R. § 37.103(d), including the requirement that these new vans either be accessible or 
24  that Uber’s overall transportation service meet the equivalent service requirement.  
25 
136.  Upon information and belief, even if Xchange Leasing, LLC was not controlled by 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 25 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 26 of 33
 
1  Uber, Uber’s partnership with Xchange Leasing, LLC demonstrates that Uber has reasonable 
2  options it can utilize put WAVs on the road and make its service meaningfully accessible.  
3 
137.  On or about January 30, 2018, Uber, Xchange Leasing, and a company known as 
4 
Fair announced that the portfolio of Xchange Leasing had been purchased by Fair.22  
5 
138.  According  to  the  press  release  “Fair  will  be  the  exclusive  long-term  vehicle 
6 
solutions partner to Uber in the U.S. for drivers seeking vehicle access for 30 days or longer, and 
7 
together the companies will work to develop customized new offerings that fit the needs of drivers, 
8 
as well as integrations into Uber's products for drivers.” 
9 
139.  Upon information, despite the fact that Uber could be working with its exclusive 
10 
partner Fair, Uber has not taken steps to make its service in Jackson meaningfully accessible.   
11 
140.  Upon information  and belief, even if there is  no regulatory requirement  that 
12 
13  explicitly requires Uber to meet the equivalency standard, providing an equivalent level of service 
14  for  individuals  with  disabilities  who  use  wheelchair  would  be  a  reasonable 
15  accommodation/modification.  
16 
G.  Uber Forbids Most WAVs from Operating on its Platform. 
17  141.  For each city where Uber operates, Uber sets out certain requirements for the 
18 
vehicles that can be used on its platform. And if “the vehicle does not meet Uber’s requirements 
19 
it’s not allowed to participate in Uber’s products.” If “a vehicle doesn’t meet these requirements, 
20 
they are not allowed to drive for Uber's products,” Uber knows of “no exceptions.” 
21 
142.  In New Orleans and Jackson, MS, for a vehicle to participate in UberX, Uber 
22 
requires that the vehicle “must be a four-door vehicle, have five factory-installed seats, [and] air 
23 
24 
 
22 https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/fair-and-uber-announce-strategic-partnership-fair-
25 
acquires-xchange-leasing-portfolio-300589935.html (last accessed October 8, 2018).  
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 26 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 27 of 33
 
1  conditioning” and it explicitly prohibits “vans, box trucks, or similar vehicles, [and] aftermarket 
2  seating modifications.” If “a vehicle doesn't meet these criteria, Uber will not allow it to participate 
3 
in Uber's UberX product.”  
4 
143.  Similarly, in New Orleans and Jackson, MS, Uber’s UberXL product requires 
5 
“seven seats, and no aftermarket modifications, and no vans.” 
6 
144.  These requirements have been in place since the inception of this lawsuit and 
7 
continue to be in place.  
8 
145.  But most WAVs are vans that have been altered through after-market modifications 
9 
to make them usable for persons with motorized wheelchairs. 
10 
146.  As  a  result,  Uber’s  “no  vans”  rule,  its  minimum  seat  rule,  and  its  ban  on 
11 
“aftermarket seating modifications” screen out most WAVs. 
12 
13  IV.   CAUSE OF ACTION 
14  VIOLATION OF TITLE III  
OF THE AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT 
15   
147.  Plaintiff re-alleges and incorporates by reference the above allegations set forth in 
16 
the Complaint as if fully set forth herein. 
17 
148.  Title III of the ADA prohibits discrimination against persons with disabilities by 
18 
places of public accommodation and by private entities providing certain services, including 
19 
20  specified public transportation services. Spector v. Norwegian Cruise Line Ltd., 545 U.S. 119, 128 
21  (2005) (“Title III of the ADA prohibits discrimination against the disabled in the full and equal 
22  enjoyment of public accommodations, 42 U.S.C. § 12182(a), and public transportation services, § 
23 
12184(a).”); 42 U.S.C. § 12182 (“Prohibition of discrimination by public accommodations”); 42 
24 
U.S  .C.  §  12184  (“Prohibition  of  discrimination  in  specified  public  transportation  services 
25 
provided by private entities”). 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 27 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 28 of 33
 
1  149.  “The term ‘specified public transportation’ means transportation by bus, rail, or any 
2  other conveyance (other than by aircraft) that provides the general public with general or special 
3 
service (including charter service) on a regular and continuing basis.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(10). 
4 
Public transportation services include “demand responsive systems,” which means “any system of 
5 
providing transportation of individuals by a vehicle, other than a system which is a fixed route 
6 
system.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(3). 
7 
150.  In  addition,  regulations  promulgated  by  the  United  States  Secretary  of 
8 
Transportation provide that: “No entity shall discriminate against an individual with a disability in 
9 
connection with the provision of transportation service.” 49 C.F.R. § 37.5(a).  
10 
151.  Defendants provide a demand responsive transportation system as defined by 42 
11 
U.S.C. § 12181. Defendants have been held to be a covered entity under Title III of the ADA. 
12 
13  See, e.g., Ramos v. Uber Technologies, 2015 WL 758087 at *5-6 (W.D. Tex., Feb. 20, 2015). 
14  152.  Under Section 12184(a)(2) of the ADA, discrimination includes the failure of 
15  an entity to: 
16 
(A)   make reasonable modifications consistent with those required under section 
17 
12182(b)(2)(A)(ii) of this title; 
18 
153.  Under Section 12182(b)(2)(C)(i) of the ADA, discrimination can also include: “a 
19 
failure of a private entity which operates a demand responsive system and which is not subject to 
20 
section 12184 of this title to operate such system so that, when viewed in its entirety, such system 
21 
ensures  a  level  of  service  to  individuals  with  disabilities,  including  individuals  who  use 
22 
wheelchairs, equivalent to the level of service provided to individuals without disabilities.” 
23 
24 
25 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 28 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 29 of 33
 
1  154.  “Equivalent” is defined under the ADA’s regulations at 49 CFR § 37.105 to mean 
2  “equivalent  to  the  service  provided  other  individuals  with  respect  to  the  following  service 
3 
characteristics: 
4 
  (a)   (1) Schedules/headways (if the system is fixed route); 
(2) Response time (if the system is demand responsive); 
5 
  (b) Fares; 
  (c) Geographic area of service; 
6 
  (d) Hours and days of service; 
7    (e) Availability of information; 
  (f) Reservations capability (if the system is demand responsive); 
8    (g) Any constraints on capacity or service availability; 
(h) Restrictions priorities based on trip purpose (if the system is demand responsive). 
9   
155.  Defendants and their service providers have failed to provide any mechanism by 
10 
which to adequately serve individuals with mobility-related disabilities such as Plaintiff or others 
11 
similarly situated. Moreover, Defendants have refused to make reasonable accommodations in 
12 
13  policies, practices, and procedures to allow full use and enjoyment of their transportation services 
14  by Plaintiff.  
15  156.  Defendants have discriminated and are discriminating against Plaintiff in violation 
16 
of the ADA by failing to provide accessible transportation services. 
17 
157.  Defendants  continue  to  discriminate  against  the  Plaintiff  by  failing  to  make 
18 
reasonable  modifications  in  policies,  practices  or  procedures,  when  such  modifications  are 
19 
necessary to afford accessible transportation services to individuals with disabilities. 
20 
158.  Plaintiff has been injured by the discrimination they encountered when they were 
21 
excluded from using Defendants’ transportation services and they continue to be injured by their 
22 
inability to patronize Defendants’ services. He has additionally been injured by the stigma of 
23 
Defendants’ discrimination. 
24 
25 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 29 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 30 of 33
 
1  159.  Plaintiff’s injuries are traceable to Defendants’ discriminatory conduct, policies, or 
2  lack of policies alleged herein and will be redressed by the relief requested. Plaintiff has been 
3 
injured and will continue to be injured by Defendants’ failure to comply with the ADA and 
4 
Defendants’ ongoing, continued acts of discrimination. 
5 
160.  Defendants have control over their drivers’ ADA compliance. For example, a  
6 
term of the contract between Uber and its drivers bars drivers from denying users who have service 
7 
animals:  
8 
You  understand  and  agree  that  you  have  a  legal  obligation  under  the 
9  Americans with Disabilities Act and similar state laws to transport Users with 
Service Animals (as defined by applicable state and federal law), including 
10 
guide dogs for the blind and visually impaired Users, and there is no exception 
to this obligation for allergies or religious objections. Your knowing failure 
11 
to transport a User with a Service Animal shall constitute a material breach 
of this Agreement. You agree that a “knowing failure” to comply with this 
12 
legal obligation shall constitute either: (1) a denial of a ride where you state 
13  the denial was due to a Service Animal; or (2) there is more than one (1) 
instance in which a User or the companion of a User alleges that you cancelled 
14  or refused a ride on the basis of a Service Animal.   
 
15  161.  The Uber contract with drivers does not, however, have a provision barring drivers 
16 
from denying service to wheelchair users.  
17 
162.  As a result of their inability to use Defendants’ services, Plaintiff is suffering 
18 
irreparable harm. 
19 
163.  Although Plaintiff has not downloaded or used the Uber Application, Title III of 
20 
the ADA does not “require a person with a disability to engage in a futile gesture if such person 
21 
has actual notice that a person or organization covered by this subchapter does not intend to comply 
22 
with its provisions.” 42 U.S.C. § 12188; Pickern v. Holiday Quality Foods, Inc., 293 F.3d 1133, 
23 
1136–37  (9th  Cir.2002)  (“under  the  ADA,  once  a  plaintiff  has  actually  become  aware  of 
24 
discriminatory conditions existing at a public accommodation, and is thereby deterred from 
25 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 30 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 31 of 33
 
1  visiting or patronizing that accommodation, the plaintiff has suffered an injury,” and “[s]o long as 
2  the discriminatory conditions continue, and so long as a plaintiff is aware of them and remains 
3 
deterred, the injury under the ADA continues”). 
4 
164.  Here,  Plaintiff  has  been  excluded  from  Defendants’  services  as  a  result  of 
5 
Defendants’ refusal to provide a reasonable accommodation/modification, as is outlined above. 
6 
Defendants’  refusal  to  provide  service  to  people  with  disabilities  in  Jackson  is  a  topic  of 
7 
conversation  among  Plaintiff’s  community.  Plaintiff  has  researched  online  and  found  that 
8 
UberACCESS, UberASSIST, and UberWAV are offered in other cities but not in Jackson.   
9 
165.  Plaintiff possesses smart phones, credit cards, and money such that they could sign 
10 
up as Uber users. However, Plaintiff has experienced the humiliation of past denials of services, 
11 
including transportation services, in other contexts, and so chose not to engage in a process they 
12 
13  know to be futile with Uber.  
14  166.  Furthermore, and independent of the above, 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(1) makes it 
15  unlawful to impose eligibility criteria that “screen out or tend to screen out” any “class of 
16 
individuals with disabilities from fully enjoying the specified public transportation services” unless 
17 
“necessary for the provision of the services being offered.”  
18 
167.  Uber  has  violated  42  U.S.C.  §  12184(b)(1)  by  imposing  eligibility  criteria 
19 
(specifically, its “no vans” rule, its ban on “aftermarket seating modifications,” and its minimum 
20 
seat rule) that screens out most WAVs, which prevents a “class of individuals” with disabilities – 
21 
specifically those persons who use motorized wheelchairs – from fully enjoying the specified 
22 
public transportation services.  
23 
168.  Excluding WAVs is not “necessary for the provision of the services being offered.”  
24 
25 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 31 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 218   Filed 10/20/21   Page 32 of 33
 
1  169.  Pursuant  to  42  U.S.C.  §  12188,  this  Court  has  authority  to  grant  Plaintiff’s 
2  injunctive relief, including an Order that Defendants’ transportation services are in violation of the 
3 
ADA and requiring Defendants to alter the Uber Application to make it accessible to and useable 
4 
by individuals with mobility disabilities to the full extent required by Title III of the ADA. 
5 
  VI.   RELIEF REQUESTED 
6 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff demands judgment against Defendants, and request the 
7 
following relief: 
8 
A.  That this Court declare that Defendants’ policies, procedures, and services have been 
9 
provided in a discriminatory manner which violates the ADA;  
10 
B.  That this Court declare that Defendants failed to provide Plaintiff with a reasonable 
11 
accommodation/modification;  
12 
13  C.  That this Court Order injunctive relief to require Defendants to bring their application 
14  and transportation services into compliance and remain in compliance with the 
15  requirements of the ADA;  
16 
D.  That this Court supervise the injunctive relief entered and ensure that Uber complies with 
17 
the requested injunctive relief within a reasonable period of time, to be determined by 
18 
this Court;  
19 
E.  That this Court award reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs (including expert fees) and other 
20 
expenses of suit; and    
21 
F.  That this Court award such other and further relief as it deems necessary, just, proper, and 
22 
appropriate.   
23 
Respectfully submitted,  
24 
 
By Plaintiff, by and through their counsel, 
25 
 
  PLAINTIFF’S SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 32

- 1 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 2 of 25
 
1  I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
2  1.  STEPHAN NAMISNAK is a person with a disability who lives in New Orleans, 
3  Louisiana. MR. NAMISNAK has Muscular Dystrophy.  
4  2.  FRANCIS  FALLS  is  a  person  with  a  disability  who  lives  in  New  Orleans, 
5  Louisiana. MR. FALLS is afflicted with paraplegia as a result of a spinal cord injury. MR. FALLS 
6  is also missing his right arm.  
7  3.  MITCHELL MIRAGLIA is a person with a disability who lives in New Orleans, 
8  Louisiana. MR. MIRAGLIA is a quadriplegic who has cerebral palsy and requires a wheelchair 
9  for mobility.  
10  4.  Each of the named Plaintiffs use an electric wheelchair to get from place to place. 
11  Plaintiffs  can  do  practically  everything  a  non-disabled  person  can  do  with  the  appropriate 
12  accommodations for their disability – work, travel, and enjoy life. However, Plaintiffs are not able 
13  to drive. As a result, Plaintiffs primarily rely on public transportation to get around the New 
14  Orleans metro area.  
15  5.  Defendants  Uber  Technologies,  Inc.  and  Rasier,  LLC  (collectively,  “Uber”) 
16  provide a mobile-phone app service that allows users to call a car to drive them from point A to 
17  point B for a fee. The app also allows people who own cars to sign up as drivers to provide those 
18  rides.  
19  6.  Uber is operating a nation-wide demand-responsive transportation system.  
20  7.  In  some  cities,  Uber  has  options  for  disabled  users  who  use  wheelchairs.  For 
21  example, if a user is in San Francisco, Portland, or Washington, D.C., they are shown an icon in the 
22  Uber app for “Uber Access.” By selecting that icon, those users shown options – UberASSIST 
23  and/or UberWAV. UberASSIST allows a person with a disability to hail a driver who has been 
24  specifically trained to assist riders into vehicles and who can accommodate folding wheelchairs, 
- 2 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 3 of 25
 
1  walkers,  and  scooters.  UberWAV  allows  a  person  with  a  disability  to  hail  a  driver  with  a 
2  wheelchair-accessible vehicle. 
3  8.  Due to Plaintiffs’ need for a heavy electric wheelchair that cannot be folded up and 
4  placed in a car’s trunk, they are unable to utilize UberASSIST. However, Plaintiffs could benefit 
5  and utilize UberWAV – if it was available in New Orleans.  
6  9.  Unfortunately, Defendants have refused to make the UberWAV program available to 
7  New Orleans users. 
8  10.  As a result of Uber’s refusal to make UberWAV available in New Orleans, persons 
9  with disabilities in New Orleans have no ability to call an accessible vehicle through the Uber app 
10  that will accommodate their needs. Even if there are drivers on the road who have such a vehicle or 
11  training, there is no way for a New Orleans users to find an UberWAV vehicle through the app. For 
12  this reason, Plaintiffs are excluded from Uber’s transportation services and application.  
13  11.  Under the Americans With Disabilities Act, Uber is required to make reasonable 
14  modifications to its services, provide auxiliary aids and services, and remove barriers that deter 
15  persons with disabilities. Uber is plainly able to do these things – as evidenced by the fact that they 
16  offer UberWAV elsewhere. Furthermore, Uber’s ability to revise their app is evident by their 
17  periodic special promotions in which they alter the app to connect users to puppies, cake, and 
18  donuts for a single day.  For example, on the evening of the filing of this Complaint, Uber is hosting 
19  a free, “secret” music concert in New Orleans that can only be reached by taking an Uber – and is 
20  therefore completely inaccessible to Plaintiffs. Despite their clear ability to alter the app, defendants 
21  have chosen not to provide sufficient wheelchair-accessible services in New Orleans, Louisiana.  
22  12.  As  such,  Uber  has  violated  their  legal  obligations  under  the  Americans  With 
23  Disabilities  Act  (“ADA”),  42  U.S.C.  §  12181,  et  seq.,  the  California  Disabled  Persons  Act, 
24 
- 3 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 4 of 25
 
1  California Civil Code § 54 et seq. (“CDPA”), and California's Unfair Competition Law (“UCL”) 
2  (Business & Professions Code § 17200 et seq.)  
3  13.  According to the U.S. Department of Justice, Title III lawsuits over inaccessible 
4  transportation go “to the very heart of the ADA’s goals ‘to assure equality of opportunity, full 
5  participation, independent living, and economic self-sufficiency’ for individuals with disabilities.”1 
6  Plaintiffs seek to vindicate the promises of federal and state law. 
7  II. JURISDICTION AND PARTIES 
8  14.  Jurisdiction: This is an action for relief pursuant to Title III of the Americans With 
9  Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. § 12181 et seq. This Court is vested with original jurisdiction pursuant 
10  to 28 U.S.C. § 1331 and 1343. This court is vested with supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiff’s 
11  state  law  claims  pursuant  to  28  U.S.C.  §  1367  as  this  claim  arises  out  of  the  same  case  or 
12  controversy as the federal claim. 
13  15.  Intradistrict Assignment: Because the claims described infra arose in the County of 
14  San Francisco, this case should be assigned to the San Francisco or Oakland Division of the 
15  Northern District of California per Local Rule 3-2(d). 
16  16.  Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b) because Defendants 
17  are headquartered in San Francisco, California.    
18  17.  Plaintiff  STEPHAN  NAMISNAK  is  a  citizen  and  resident  of  New  Orleans, 
19  Louisiana. He uses an electric wheelchair for mobility. He is disabled within the meaning of the 
20  ADA. Mr. Namisnak’s motorized wheelchair cannot be folded into the trunk of a car. 
21  18.  Plaintiff FRANCIS FALLS is a citizen and resident of New Orleans, Louisiana. He 
22  uses an electric wheelchair for mobility. He is disabled within the meaning of the ADA. He requires 
23 
                                                 
24  1 National Federation of the Blind of California v. Uber Technologies, Inc., N. D. Cal. 14-cv-4086, 
R. Doc. 29 at 4. 
- 4 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 5 of 25
 
1  wheelchair accessible vehicles for transportation. He uses a motorized wheelchair that cannot be 
2  folded into the trunk of a car. 
3  19.  Plaintiff  MITCHELL  MIRAGLIA  is  a  citizen  and  resident  of  New  Orleans, 
4  Louisiana. He uses an electric wheelchair for mobility. He is disabled within the meaning of the 
5  ADA. Mr. Miraglia’s motorized wheelchair cannot be folded into the trunk of a car. 
6  20.  Defendant UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC. is a foreign corporation, organized 
7  under the laws of the  State of Delaware,  with  its principal  place of  business  located in  San 
8  Francisco, California. Uber Technologies, Inc.’s subsidiary, Rasier, LLC is registered with the 
9  Louisiana Secretary of State as charter number 41604705F.  
10  21.  Defendant RASIER, LLC is a foreign corporation, organized under the laws of the 
11  State of Delaware, with its principal place of business located in San Francisco, California. Rasier, 
12  LLC is registered with the Louisiana Secretary of State as charter number 41585719Q. 
13  22.  Together,  Defendants  provide  an  extremely  popular  vehicles-for-hire  service 
14  whereby Uber drivers pick up customers and provide them with transportation in an automobile. 
15  Defendants  do not provide vehicles-for-hire services to mobility-impaired consumers  in  New 
16  Orleans  who  require  wheelchair-accessible  transportation  vehicles  that  can  accommodate  an 
17  electric wheelchair.  
18  III.  FACTS 
19  Defendants Operate a Vehicle-for-Hire Transportation System in New Orleans  
20  23.  Uber pioneered the vehicle-for-hire market across the United States. Anyone with 
21  access  to  a  smartphone  can  request  travel  services  from  Uber.  Uber’s  customers  use  a 
22  smartphone application to locate, schedule, and pay for their travel. Consumers enter into contracts 
23  and  business  relationships  by contacting  Uber  via electronic notification  using an  application 
24  downloaded to their smartphone (hereinafter known as the “Uber Application”). Upon receipt of a

1  92.  Title III of the ADA prohibits discrimination against persons with disabilities by 
2  places  of  public  accommodation  and  by  private  entities  providing  certain  services,  including 
3  specified public transportation services. Spector v. Norwegian Cruise Line Ltd., 545 U.S. 119, 128 
4  (2005) (“Title III of the ADA prohibits discrimination against the disabled in the full and equal 
5  enjoyment of public accommodations, 42 U.S.C. § 12182(a), and public transportation services, § 
6  12184(a).”); 42 U.S.C. § 12182 (“Prohibition of discrimination by public accommodations”); 42 
7  U.S .C. § 12184 (“Prohibition of discrimination in specified public transportation services provided 
8  by private entities”). 
9  93.  “The term ‘specified public transportation’ means transportation by bus, rail, or any 
10  other conveyance (other than by aircraft) that provides the general public with general or special 
11  service (including charter service) on a regular and continuing basis.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(10). 
12  Public transportation services include “demand responsive systems,” which means “any system of 
13  providing transportation of individuals by a vehicle, other than a system which is a fixed route 
14  system.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(3). 
15  94.  In  addition,  regulations  promulgated  by  the  United  States  Secretary  of 
16  Transportation provide that: “No entity shall discriminate against an individual with a disability in 
17  connection with the provision of transportation service.” 49 C.F.R. § 37.5(a).  
18  95.  Defendants provide a demand responsive transportation system as defined by 42 
19  U.S.C. § 12181. Defendants have been held to be a covered entity under Title III of the ADA. 
20  See, e.g., Ramos v. Uber Technologies, 2015 WL 758087 at *5-6 (W.D. Tex., Feb. 20, 2015). 
21  96.  Under Section 12184(a)(2) of the ADA, discrimination includes the failure of an 
22  entity to: 
23  (A)   make reasonable modifications consistent with those required under section 
12182(b)(2)(A)(ii) of this title; 
24  (B)   provide auxiliary aids and services consistent with the requirements of section 
12182(b)(2)(A)(iii) of this title; and 
- 18 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 19 of 25
 
1  (C)   remove barriers consistent with the requirements of section 12182(b)(2)(A) of 
this title and with the requirements of section 12183(a)(2) of this title; 
2   
97.  Under Section 12182(b)(2)(C)(i) of the ADA, discrimination can also include: “a 
3 
failure of a private entity which operates a demand responsive system and which is not subject to 
4 
section 12184 of this title to operate such system so that, when viewed in its entirety, such system 
5 
ensures  a  level  of  service  to  individuals  with  disabilities,  including  individuals  who  use 
6 
wheelchairs, equivalent to the level of service provided to individuals without disabilities.” 
7 
98.  “Equivalent” is defined under the ADA’s regulations at 49 CFR § 37.105 to mean 
8 
“equivalent  to  the  service  provided  other  individuals  with  respect  to  the  following  service 
9 
characteristics: 
10 
(a)   (1) Schedules/headways (if the system is fixed route); 
11    (2) Response time (if the system is demand responsive); 
(b) Fares; 
12  (c) Geographic area of service; 
(d) Hours and days of service; 
13  (e) Availability of information; 
(f) Reservations capability (if the system is demand responsive); 
14  (g) Any constraints on capacity or service availability; 
  (h) Restrictions priorities based on trip purpose (if the system is demand responsive).

1  necessary to afford accessible transportation services to individuals with disabilities; and by failing 
2  to take such efforts that may be necessary to ensure that no individual with a disability is excluded, 
3  denied  goods  and  services,  segregated  or  otherwise  treated  differently  than  other  individuals 
4  because of the absence of auxiliary aids and services. 
5  102.  Additionally, by failing to provide access options to New Orleans users who require 
6  an electric wheelchair, Defendants have failed to meet the requirements of 49 C.F.R. § 37.167 that 
7  “the entity shall make available to individuals with disabilities adequate information concerning 
8  transportation  services,  [which]  includes  making  adequate  communications  capacity  available, 
9  though accessible formats and technology, to enable users to obtain information and schedule 
10  service.”  
11  103.  Defendants have discriminated and are discriminating against Plaintiffs in violation 
12  of the ADA by failing to make a place a public accommodation accessible to Plaintiffs. Namely, 
13  Defendants have failed to provide a means by which Plaintiffs can access the free, secret Galantis 
14  show. This show is available and accessible to persons who do not have a disability that requires 
15  them to utilize an electric wheelchair.    
16  104.  Plaintiffs have been injured by the discrimination they encountered when they were 
17  deterred from using Defendants’ transportation services and they continue to be injured by their 
18  inability to patronize Defendants’ services. They have additionally been injured by the stigma of 
19  Defendants’ discrimination. 
20  105.  Plaintiffs’ injuries are traceable to Defendants’ discriminatory conduct, policies, or 
21  lack of policies alleged herein and will be redressed by the relief requested. Plaintiffs have been 
22  injured and will continue to be injured by Defendants’ failure to comply with the ADA and 
23  Defendants’ ongoing, continued acts of discrimination. 
24 
- 20 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 21 of 25
 
1  106.  Defendants  have  control  over  their  drivers’  ADA  compliance.  For  example,  a  
2  term of the contract between Uber and its drivers bars drivers from denying users who have service 
3  animals:  
4  You understand and agree that you have a legal obligation under the Americans 
with  Disabilities  Act  and  similar  state  laws  to  transport  Users  with  Service 
5  Animals (as defined by applicable state and federal law), including guide dogs for 
the blind and visually impaired Users, and there is no exception to this obligation 
6  for allergies or religious objections. Your knowing failure to transport a User with 
a Service Animal shall constitute a material breach of this Agreement. You agree 
7  that a “knowing failure” to comply with this legal obligation shall constitute 
either: (1) a denial of a ride where you state the denial was due to a Service 
8  Animal;  or  (2)  there  is  more  than  one  (1)  instance  in  which  a  User  or  the 
companion of a User alleges that you cancelled or refused a ride on the basis of a 
9  Service Animal.   
 
10  107.  The Uber contract with drivers does not, however, have a provision barring drivers 
11  from denying service to wheelchair users.  
12  108.  As a result of their inability to use Defendants’ services, Plaintiffs are suffering 
13  irreparable harm. 
14  109.  Although Plaintiffs have not downloaded or used the Uber Application, Title III of 
15  the ADA does not “require a person with a disability to engage in a futile gesture if such person has 
16  actual notice that a person or organization covered by this subchapter does not intend to comply 
17  with its provisions.” 42 U.S.C. § 12188; Pickern v. Holiday Quality Foods, Inc., 293 F.3d 1133, 
18  1136–37  (9th  Cir.2002)  (“under  the  ADA,  once  a  plaintiff  has  actually  become  aware  of 
19  discriminatory conditions existing at a public accommodation, and is thereby deterred from visiting 
20  or patronizing that accommodation, the plaintiff has suffered an injury,” and “[s]o long as the 
21  discriminatory conditions continue, and so long as a plaintiff is aware of them and remains deterred, 
22  the injury under the ADA continues”). 
23  110.  Here, Plaintiffs are being deterred from patronizing Defendants’ services as a result 
24  of their personal knowledge of the violations stated above. Defendants’ refusal to provide service to 
- 21 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 22 of 25
 
1  people with disabilities in New Orleans is a topic of conversation among Plaintiffs’ community. 
2  Plaintiffs are aware that UberWAV is offered in other cities but not in New Orleans.   
3  111.  Plaintiffs have experienced the difficulty and frustration of past denials of services, 
4  including transportation services, in other contexts, and so chose not to engage in a process they 
5  know to be futile with Uber.  
6  112.  Pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 12188, this Court has authority to grant Plaintiffs’ injunctive 
7  relief, including an Order that Defendants’ transportation services are in violation of the ADA and 
8  requiring  Defendants’  to  alter  the  Uber  Application  to  make  it  accessible  to  and  useable  by 
9  individuals with mobility disabilities to the full extent required by Title III of the ADA. 
10   
11   
12  COUNT II - VIOLATION OF THE  
CALIFORNIA DISABLED PERSONS ACT 
13   
113.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference the above allegations set forth in the 
14 
Complaint as if fully set forth herein. 
15 
114.  Pursuant to the remedies, procedures, and rights set forth in Cal. Civ. Code § 52, 
16 
Plaintiffs pray for judgment as set forth below. 
17 
115.  Defendants operate, within the jurisdiction of the State of California, places of public 
18 
accommodation and/or places to which the general public is invited and, as such, is obligated to 
19 
comply with the provisions of the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA), Cal. Civ. Code § 54, et 
20 
seq.  
21 
116.  The conduct alleged herein violated the CDPA, including without limitation Cal. 
22 
Civ. Code, § 54.1, et seq. The CDPA guarantees, inter alia, that persons with disabilities are 
23 
entitled to full and equal access, as other members of the general public, to accommodations, 
24 
advantages, facilities, and privileges of covered entities. 
- 22 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 23 of 25
 
1  117.  Defendants have violated the CDPA by, inter alia, denying Plaintiff and members of 
2  the proposed class, as persons with disabilities, full and equal access, as other members of the 
3  general public, to accommodations, advantages, and facilities offered by Defendants. 
4  118.  Defendants have violated the CDPA by, inter alia, failing to operate their services 
5  on  a  nondiscriminatory  basis  and  failing  to  ensure  that  persons  with  disabilities  have 
6  nondiscriminatory access to their transportation services. 
7  119.  In committing the acts and/or omissions alleged herein, Defendants wrongfully and 
8  unlawfully denied access to their transportation services to individuals with disabilities and acted 
9  with knowledge of the effect their conduct was having on persons with physical disabilities. 
10  120.  Defendants have violated the CDPA by being, as listed above, in violation of both 
11  California Standards and the ADA.  Plaintiffs are not required to prove intent or actual damages to 
12  recover minimum statutory damages under the CPDA. 
13  121.  Plaintiffs are deterred  from patronizing Defendants’ transportation services as  a 
14  result of their actual knowledge of the violations stated above. 
15  122.  Pursuant to the remedies, procedures, and rights set forth in California law, including 
16  Cal. Civ. Code § 54, Plaintiff prays for judgment as set forth below. 
17  COUNT III – VIOLATION OF CALIFORNIA’S UNFAIR COMPETITION LAW  
18  123.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference the above allegations set forth in the 
19  Complaint as if fully set forth herein. 
20  124.  California's  Unfair  Competition  Law  (“UCL”)  (Business  &  Professions  Code  § 
21  17200  et  seq.) bars  “unfair  competition,”  which  includes  any  “unlawful,  unfair  or  fraudulent 
22  business act or practice and unfair, deceptive, untrue or misleading advertising.” 
23  125.  In passing the UCL, the legislature “intended to permit courts to enjoin ongoing 
24  wrongful business conduct in whatever context such activity might occur.” Comm. on Children’s 
- 23 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 24 of 25
 
1  Television, Inc. v. Gen. Foods Corp., 35 Cal. 3d 197, 210 (1983). 
2  126.  The UCL  “‘borrows’ violations of other laws  and treats  these violations, when 
3  committed pursuant to business activity, as unlawful practices independently actionable under [the 
4  UCL].” Farmers Ins. Exch. v. Super. Ct., 2 Cal. 4th 377, 383 (1992); Clerkin v. MyLife.com, Inc., 
5  No. C 11– 00527 CW, 2011 WL 3607496, at *6 (N.D. Cal. Aug. 16, 2011) (“Violation of almost 
6  any federal, state or local law may serve as the basis for a UCL claim.”). 
7  127.  Defendants business practices described above are unfair competition under the UCL 
8  because they violate the ADA and CDPA. 
9  128.  Defendants business practices described above are unfair competition also because 
10  Defendants’  failure  to  provide  accommodations  gives  them  an  unfair  advantage  relative  to 
11  traditional taxi cab companies.  
12  129.  As a result of Defendants unfair competition business practices described above, 
13  Plaintiffs have suffered injury in fact and have lost money. For example, they have been forced to 
14  take more expensive taxi cabs, thus losing money.  
15  V. JURY DEMAND 
16  130.  Plaintiffs request a trial by jury.  
17  VI. RELIEF REQUESTED 
18    WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs demand judgment against Defendants, and request the following 
19  relief: 
20  A.  that this Court declare that Defendants’ policies, procedures, and services have been 
21  provided in a discriminatory manner which violates the ADA, the California Disabled 
22  Persons Act, and California’s Business & Professions Code § 17200;  
23  B.  that this Court declare that Defendants’ violations of the anti-discrimination statutes of 
24  California were intentional; 
- 24 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 25 of 25
 
1  C.  that this Court Order injunctive relief to require Defendants to bring their transportation 
2  service into compliance and remain in compliance with state and federal anti-discrimination 
3  statutes;  
4  D.  that this Court award damages in restitution to Plaintiffs;  
5  E.  that this Court award reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs (including expert fees) and other 
6  expenses of suit; and    
7  F.  that this Court award such other and further relief as it deems necessary, just, proper, and 
8  appropriate.   
9  Respectfully submitted, this the twenty-sixth day of October, 2017, 
 
10  By Plaintiffs, by and through their counsel, 
 
11

documents.title: Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Motion to Dismiss Second Amended Complaint
documents.text:
Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 1 of 12
 
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6   
7  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
9   
STEPHAN NAMISNAK, et al., 
10  Case No.  17-cv-06124-RS    
Plaintiffs,   
11   
v.  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND 
a  12    DENYING IN PART MOTION TO 
rt ni UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC., et al.,  DISMISS SECOND AMENDED 
ouor 13  COMPLAINT 
t Calif Defendants. 
cC 14   
i
strof     
Dict  15  I.  INTRODUCTION 
s ri
et
tatDis 16    Stephen Namisnak and Francis Falls bring this action against Uber Technologies, Inc. and 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  its subsidiary Rasier, LLC for failure to make reasonable accommodations under federal disability 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  law. The case was stayed for a year while the parties attempted mediation. Defendants now move 
19  to dismiss the Second Amended Complaint (“SAC”), arguing plaintiffs have no private right of 
20  action, have not been denied reasonable modifications, and have otherwise failed to state a claim. 
21  Pursuant to Civil Local Rule 7-1(b), the motion is suitable for disposition without oral argument, 
22  and the hearing set for April 2, 2020 is vacated. For the reasons set forth below, the motion to 
23  dismiss is granted in part and denied in part. 
24  II.  BACKGROUND 
25  Uber operates a ride-for-hire service that utilizes a mobile phone application (“app”) to 
26  connect riders with drivers who have signed up with the app. The Uber app offers users services 
27  which vary from locality to locality. In some cities, such as Portland, San Francisco, Los Angeles, 
28  and Washington, D.C., the app displays an icon called “Uber Access.” When a user taps on the 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 2 of 12
 
1  icon, two options appear: “UberASSIST” and “UberWAV.” UberASSIST connects app users with 
2  specially trained drivers who will assist riders into vehicles and can accommodate folding 
3  wheelchairs, walkers, and scooters. UberWAV offers app users the option to call a wheelchair-
4  accessible vehicle, i.e. a “WAV.” 
5  Plaintiffs are persons with disabilities who live in New Orleans. Falls has paraplegia as the 
6  result of a spiral cord injury and is missing his right arm. Namisnak has muscular dystrophy. Both 
7  use electric wheelchairs for mobility. These wheelchairs cannot be folded or stored in the trunk of 
8  a car, because they are too heavy. Because plaintiffs cannot drive, they use public transportation to 
9  get around. Since the Uber app in New Orleans does not provide UberWAV, plaintiffs are unable 
10  to use the service.1 Accordingly, plaintiffs allege, Uber has violated its obligations under the 
11  Americans with Disabilities Act (“ADA”). 
12  Plaintiffs have never downloaded the Uber app because they are aware UberWAV is not 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  offered, and their electric wheelchairs do not fit into standard cars. If Uber were to offer in New 
Cif
t al
cC 14  Orleans a service, such as UberWAV, which accommodated electronic wheelchairs, plaintiffs 
i
strof 
Dict  15  would use it. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief under Title III of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  12181 et seq. 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  III.  LEGAL STANDARD 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18    Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) governs motions to dismiss for failure to state a 
19  claim. A complaint must contain a short and plain statement of the claim showing the pleader is 
20  entitled to relief. Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a). While “detailed factual allegations” are not required, a 
21  complaint must have sufficient factual allegations to “state a claim to relief that is plausible on its 
22  face.” Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (quoting Bell Atlantic v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 
23  544, 570 (2007)). A Rule 12(b)(6) motion tests the legal sufficiency of the claims alleged in the 
24  complaint. See Parks Sch. of Bus., Inc. v. Symington, 51 F.3d 1480, 1484 (9th Cir. 1995). Thus, 
25 
 
26  1 UberASSIST is also unavailable in New Orleans. However, plaintiffs allege they could not use 
UberASSIST, even if it were an option, because that service does not accommodate non-folding, 
27  electric wheelchairs. 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
2 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 3 of 12
 
1  dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) may be based on either the “lack of a cognizable legal theory” or on 
2  “the absence of sufficient facts alleged” under a cognizable legal theory. UMG Recordings, Inc. v. 
3  Shelter Capital Partners LLC, 718 F.3d 1006, 1014 (9th Cir. 2013). When evaluating such a 
4  motion, courts generally “accept all factual allegations in the complaint as true and construe the 
5  pleadings in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.” Knievel v. ESPN, 393 F.3d 1068, 
6  1072 (9th Cir. 2005). However, “[t]hreadbare recitals of the elements of a cause of action, 
7  supported by mere conclusory statements, do not suffice.” Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678. 
8  IV.  DISCUSSION 
9  A.  Private Right of Action 
10  Title III of the ADA authorizes suits by two classes of private persons: (i) “any person who 
11  is being subjected to discrimination on the basis of disability in violation of [Title III]” and (ii) 
12  “any person…who has reasonable grounds for believing that such person is about to be subjected 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  to discrimination in violation of section 12183 of this title.” 42 U.S.C. § 12188(a)(1) (emphasis 
Cif
t al
cC 14  added). In other words, any person who has been or is being subjected to discrimination on the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  basis of disability may sue under any provision of Title III, but a person who is “about to be 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  subjected” to discrimination may only sue for discrimination under section 12183, which concerns 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  the design, construction or alteration of commercial facilities. Id.  
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Here, plaintiffs allege that they have been and are being subjected to discrimination2 
19  because they are denied access to Uber’s service for routine activities, such as attending doctor’s 
20  appointments or civic engagement events, and running errands. They have not downloaded or 
21  attempted to use the Uber app because they have “personal knowledge” that UberWAV is not 
22  available in New Orleans and “chose not to engage in a process they know to be futile with Uber.” 
23  SAC at 30. Defendants argue plaintiffs do not have a private right of action because their 
24  allegations cannot establish that they have experienced discrimination if they have not downloaded 
25 
 
26  2 The parties agree that allegations plaintiffs are “about to be subjected” to discrimination would 
not be sufficient in this case, as plaintiffs are not suing for discrimination concerning the design, 
27  construction, or alteration of commercial facilities, as provided under section 12183. 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
3 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 4 of 12
 
1  the app. Plaintiffs contend it would be pointless “to bump their wheelchairs into inaccessible Uber 
2  vehicles.” Plaintiffs’ Memorandum in Opposition, ECF No. 100, at 11.  
3  A person with a disability is not required to “engage in a futile gesture if such person has 
4  actual notice that a person or organization covered by this subchapter does not intend to comply 
5  with its provisions.” 42 U.S.C. § 12188(a)(1). Under Ninth Circuit precedent, plaintiffs suing 
6  under Title III are not required to engage in a “futile gesture” in order to show actual injury under 
7  the ADA. See Pickern v. Holiday Quality Foods Inc., 293 F.3d 1133, 1136–37 (9th Cir. 2002). 
8  The Ninth Circuit has explicitly rejected the requirement that ADA plaintiffs “personally 
9  encounter” barriers in order to sue. See Civil Rights Educ. & Enf’t Ctr. v. Hosp. Props. Trust, 867 
10  F.3d 1093, 1099 (9th Cir. 2017) (“It is the plaintiff’s ‘actual knowledge’ of a barrier, rather than 
11  the sources of that knowledge, that is determinative.”). This principle was discussed thoroughly in 
12  several recent cases in which Uber was a defendant. Crawford v. Uber Techs., Inc., No. 17-cv-
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  02664, 2018 WL 1116725, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 1, 2018); O’Hanlon v. Uber Techs., Inc., No. 19-
Cif
t al
cC 14  cv-00675, 2019 WL 5895425, at *5 (W.D. Pa. Nov. 12, 2019) (“[A]n individual’s standing to 
i
strof 
Dict  15  bring a claim for disability discrimination under the ADA is not dependent on his/her undertaking 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  futile gestures…such plaintiffs have their own standing; their deterrence-based injury is actual, 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  cognizable and their own.”); Access Living of Metro. Chicago v. Uber Techs., Inc., 351 F. Supp. 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  3d 1141, 1150 (N.D. Ill. 2018) (“Garcia and Cooper did not have to download the app and request 
19  an Uber ride to be injured. They saw the app, learned of the lack of wheelchair-accessible rides, 
20  and want to use the app in the future but reasonably believe they cannot. That is sufficient.”); 
21  Ramos v. Uber Techs., Inc., No. 14-cv-00502, 2015 WL 758087, at *7 (W.D. Tx. Feb. 20, 2015) 
22  (“[A]n ADA plaintiff need not request services as long as they have actual notice that they would 
23  be denied services or treated in a discriminatory manner and they are being deterred from 
24  attempting to obtain the services by such knowledge.”). 
25  Plaintiffs have sufficiently alleged past and present discrimination; they need not engage in 
26  the “futile gesture” of downloading the Uber app to confirm they cannot use it. Namisnak and 
27  Falls have pled actual knowledge that the Uber app in New Orleans does not have a mechanism 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
4 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 5 of 12
 
1  for summoning a WAV vehicle. They have stated they “want to use Uber’s transportation system, 
2  but have been deterred because they know that if they tried, they would not be able to call a 
3  WAV.” SAC at 9, 22, 28–30. They have also pled that “they plan to use Uber if and when it 
4  becomes accessible for persons with motorized wheelchairs in New Orleans.” Id. at 10. At the 
5  pleading stage, plaintiffs are not required to do more than they already have in order to 
6  demonstrate past and present discrimination.   
7  B.  Failure to Provide Reasonable Modifications 
8  Defendants also argue plaintiffs have failed to allege plausibly they were denied 
9  “reasonable modifications” as defined by Title III of the ADA. Section 12184 of Title III prohibits 
10  discrimination “on the basis of disability in the full and equal enjoyment of specified public 
11  transportation services.” 42 U.S.C. § 12184(a). Under this section, discrimination includes, inter 
12  alia, failure to make reasonable modifications consistent with section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii). Id. § 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  12184(b)(2)(A). To prevail under section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii), the plaintiff must show the defendant 
Cif
t al
cC 14  failed to make a “requested reasonable modification…necessary to accommodate the plaintiff’s 
i
strof 
Dict  15  disability.” Karczewski v. DCH Mission Valley LLC, 862 F.3d 1006, 1010 (9th Cir. 2017) (quoting 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  Fortyune v. Am. Multi-Cinema, Inc., 364 F.3d 1075, 1082 (9th Cir. 2004)).  
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  Plaintiffs here contend they requested reasonable modifications in a September 2018 letter. 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  See Exhibit E, SAC, ECF No. 92-5. In that letter, they asked Uber to “utilize its resources, internal 
19  knowledge, and business know-how to change its operational policies and provide WAV service 
20  in New Orleans.” Id. The letter further communicated plaintiffs’ expectation that Uber would, 
21  within seven days of receiving it, “begin providing WAV service in New Orleans” and “ensure 
22  that a fleet of approximately 30–60 WAV vehicles are available in New Orleans” such that “any 
23  UberWAV service Uber provides in New Orleans meet the equivalency standard of 49 C.F.R. § 
24  37.105.” Id. The letter conceded that plaintiffs “cannot tell Uber how it must change its internal 
25  business practices and operations to provide WAV service in New Orleans,” because “[t]he ADA 
26  does not require [plaintiffs]…to tell Uber how to run its business.” Id. After a year-long stay in 
27  this case, Uber responded to the letter in November 2019, explaining its belief that Uber has no 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
5 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 6 of 12
 
1  affirmative obligation to provide accessible rides, but it is nevertheless “voluntarily” 
2  experimenting with UberWAV in “pilot markets.” See Exhibit A, Defendants’ Motion to Dismiss, 
3  ECF No. 98-1.3 Instead of making plaintiffs’ requested modifications, the response letter referred 
4  them to five alternative WAV service providers in the New Orleans area. Id. Uber still does not 
5  provide UberWAV in New Orleans. 
6  Plaintiffs must demonstrate both that they requested modifications, and that those requests 
7  were reasonable. In Karczewski v. DCH Mission Valley, 862 F.3d at 1006, the Ninth Circuit held a 
8  requested modification could not be deemed unreasonable for purposes of a motion to dismiss 
9  because, at this stage, a plaintiff’s plausible allegations must be credited as true, id. at 1011. 
10  Plaintiffs in Karczewski were requesting a car dealership install hand controls in some of its 
11  vehicles so mobility-limited potential buyers could test drive them. Id. at 1008. Defendants 
12  identified several potential challenges which, they argued, made the requested modification 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  difficult, expensive, and unreasonable to implement. Id. at 1011. The Ninth Circuit found that, 
Cif
t al
cC 14  even if plaintiffs’ request was revealed to be unreasonable at the summary judgment stage, it could 
i
strof 
Dict  15  not be deemed so at the motion to dismiss stage because the necessary facts had yet to be 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  developed. Id. (citing Fortyune, 364 F.3d at 1083 (“[W]hether a particular modification is 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  ‘reasonable’ involves a fact-specific, case-by-case inquiry that considers, among other factors, the 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  effectiveness of the modification in light of the nature of the disability in question and the cost to 
19  the organization that would implement it.”)). 
20  Similarly, in the present case, plaintiffs’ plausible allegations, taken as true, establish their 
21  requested modifications are not unreasonable. Plaintiffs have presented evidence that Uber 
22  provides UberWAV services in other cities, using UberWAV fleets larger than what they 
23  requested in New Orleans. They have pled that Uber can modify its app to provide additional 
24 
 
25  3 Uber’s response letter is attached to the SAC. Matters outside the pleadings are usually 
inadmissible for the purposes of deciding a Rule 12(b)(6) motion. Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(d). However, 
26  because the response letter’s authenticity is not contested, and because the SAC “necessarily 
relies” on it—the back-and-forth letters form the basis for plaintiffs’ “reasonable modification” 
27  theory—it may be considered. Lee v. City of Los Angeles, 250 F.3d 668, 688 (9th Cir. 2001). 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
6 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 7 of 12
 
1  services—as it has done with UberPUPPIES and UberDONUTS—in far less time than the almost 
2  three years since this case was filed. Furthermore, they have pled that Uber contracted with 
3  companies in some cities, and paid them support fees, in order to provide UberWAV in those 
4  markets. In other cities, Uber has advertised directly to drivers and incentivized them to provide 
5  UberWAV service. While the reasonableness of plaintiffs’ requested modifications may be 
6  challenged at a later stage, for purposes of a motion to dismiss, their allegations are plausible and 
7  must be taken as true. They establish Uber could reasonably assemble a fleet of WAVs in New 
8  Orleans and modify its app to provide UberWAV. 
9  In Uber’s response letter, the company referred plaintiffs to other WAV providers in New 
10  Orleans. Defendants argue this response was reasonable as a matter of law. A covered entity may 
11  refer a disabled individual to another entity when the individual seeks “services outside of the 
12  referring [entity]’s area of specialization.” 28 C.F.R. § 36.302(b)(1). The regulation provides an 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  example: a doctor who specializes in a certain practice area may refer a disabled patient seeking 
Cif
t al
cC 14  treatment in another practice area to a doctor who specializes thereto without running afoul of the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  ADA, if the referring doctor would do the same for a non-disabled patient. 28 C.F.R. § 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  36.302(b)(2). That is, for example, a cardiologist can refer a disabled patient with a broken arm to 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  an orthopedist, just as she would a non-disabled patient. Defendants, however, refer plaintiffs to 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  other transportation providers not because they would do the same for non-disabled riders, but 
19  because they simply do not want to accept the logistical and financial cost of serving them. A 
20  cardiologist may not send a disabled patient with a heart murmur to an orthopedist, and Uber 
21  cannot refer plaintiffs to other transportation companies. Put differently, Uber’s claim that it is 
22  “not a transportation company” strains credulity, given the company advertises itself as a 
23  “transportation system.” See SAC at 7–8. Plaintiffs are simply asking Uber to provide a service 
24  similar or identical to one it already provides: UberWAV. UberWAV cannot, by definition, lie 
25  outside the company’s “area of specialization.” 
26  Moreover, defendants’ fixation on their alleged non-obligation to provide “equivalent 
27 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
7 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 8 of 12
 
1  service” is misplaced.4 Sections 12184(b)(3) and (b)(5) of Title III provide that vehicles purchased 
2  or leased for “specific public transportation” systems must be “readily accessible to or usable by 
3  individuals with disabilities, including individuals who use wheelchairs,” unless the provider “can 
4  demonstrate that the [transportation] system…when viewed in its entirety, provides a level of 
5  service…equivalent to the level of service provided to the general public.” 42 U.S.C. § 
6  12184(b)(3); 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(5); 49 C.F.R. § 37.103. Defendants point out they do not 
7  themselves purchase or lease vehicles, and thus argue the “equivalent service” requirement does 
8  not apply to them. However, they have “not pointed to anything suggesting that an entity must 
9  own or lease vehicles to be subject to section 12184.” Access Living, 351 F. Supp. at 1159. Their 
10  citations to Toomer v. City Cab, 443 F.3d 1191, 1195 (10th Cir. 2006), and Noel v. New York City 
11  Taxi & Limousine Comm’n, 687 F.3d 63, 65 (2d Cir. 2012), are misguided; not only are those 
12  cases not binding authority, but they also did not even consider claims presented under section 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  12184(b)(2). Put differently, even if defendants were correct that they are not subject to sections 
Cif
t al
cC 14  12184(b)(3) and (5), they have not presented any evidence that they would not be subject to 
i
strof 
Dict  15  section 12184(b)(2), as discussed above. As was held in a related case, “Uber’s fixation on 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  whether WAVs are specifically required by statute is unavailing in light of the broad language of 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  the ADA.” Crawford, 2018 WL 1116725, at *4. “A covered entity under Section 12184 is subject 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  not just to the narrow requirements associated with the purchase of new vehicles, but the statute’s 
19  broader anti-discrimination mandate.” Id. 
20  C.  Failure to Provide Auxiliary Aids  
21  Defendants next argue plaintiffs have failed to allege plausibly a failure to provide 
22  auxiliary aids. Section 12184 requires covered entities to “provide auxiliary aids and services,” 42 
23  U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2)(B), to disabled individuals, unless doing so would “fundamentally alter” the 
24  nature of the provided service or “result in an undue burden,” id. § 12182(b)(2)(A)(iii). Plaintiffs 
25 
 
26  4 Defendants argue in their reply brief that plaintiffs have forfeited their claim to equivalent 
service by failing to address it in the response brief. Plaintiffs, however, do address the “equivalent 
27  service” issue. See Plaintiffs’ Memorandum in Opposition, ECF No. 100, at 14 n.78. 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
8 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 9 of 12
 
1  allege UberWAV is an “auxiliary aid or service” which defendants were obligated to, and did not, 
2  provide. Defendants argue instead that this provision of the ADA is only intended to protect the 
3  hearing and vision impaired—a group into which plaintiffs do not fall. In support of their position, 
4  defendants cite a Department of Justice rule which expressly excludes individuals with mobility 
5  impairments from the “auxiliary aids and services” provisions of the ADA. See 56 Fed. Reg. 
6  35,544-01, 35,566 (July 26, 1991) (“DOJ Rule”). 
7  The DOJ Rule was issued after a notice-and-comment process and thus is owed Chevron 
8  deference. Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc., 467 U.S. 837, 842 (1984). “First, 
9  always, is the question whether Congress has directly spoken to the precise question at issue. If the 
10  intent of Congress is clear, that is the end of the matter; for the court, as well as the agency, must 
11  give effect to the unambiguously expressed intent of Congress.” Id. at 842–43. If congressional 
12  intent is not clear, the court must determine at step two “whether the agency’s answer is based on 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  a permissible construction of the statute.” Id. at 843 (emphasis added). The agency’s interpretation 
Cif
t al
cC 14  must be deferred to unless it is unreasonable. Id. at 845. 
i
strof 
Dict  15  At step one, the first guide to Congress’s intent is the text of the statute. The ADA reads, in 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  relevant part: 
d Srn   
ee 17 
th The term “auxiliary aids and services” includes— 
nirt
Uo (A) qualified interpreters or other effective methods of making aurally 
N 18 
delivered materials available to individuals with hearing impairments; 
19  (B)  qualified  readers,  taped  texts,  or  other  effective  methods  of 
making  visually  delivered  materials  available  to  individuals  with 
20  visual impairments; 
(C) acquisition or modification of equipment or devices; and 
21 
(D) other similar services and actions. 
 
22 
42 U.S.C. § 12103(1). 
23 
  In interpreting this text, each party offers a canon of statutory interpretation. Plaintiffs 
24 
employ the rule against surplusage, which they say dictates that, if subpart (A) governs individuals 
25 
with hearing impairments, and (B) those with visual impairments, then (C) and (D) must be about 
26 
other disabled individuals, such as those with limited mobility, or they would be duplicative of (A) 
27 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
9 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 10 of 12
 
1  and (B). Defendants bring noscitur a sociis to the table, which they say requires subparts (C) and 
2  (D) to be interpreted in the context of the accompanying words, i.e. subparts (A) and (B), which 
3  limit the scope to individuals with hearing and visual impairments. Put differently, plaintiffs argue 
4  each subpart covers a type of disability; defendants assign each subpart to a means of 
5  accommodating disability. These statutory interpretations are equally reasonable. Substantive 
6  disagreements aside, then, these competing conclusions evince merely that the text is ambiguous. 
7  While other parts of the ADA—including section 12184(b)(2)(A), which covers 
8  “reasonable modifications,” as discussed above—contemplate accommodations which must be 
9  provided to those with mobility impairments, they do not foreclose that section 12184(b)(2)(B), 
10  which covers “auxiliary aids and services,” does so as well. Section 12184(b)(2)(A) is not 
11  explicitly or exclusively about individuals with mobility impairments. It could conceivably 
12  encompass the “reasonable modifications” necessary to accommodate those with hearing and 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  visual impairments as well. Neither party has cited any statutory text, legislative history, or 
Cif
t al
cC 14  caselaw to the contrary. Therefore, section 12184(b)(2)(B) may be similarly wide-reaching. 
i
strof 
Dict  15  The legislative history cited by plaintiffs also does not provide clarity. The Ninth Circuit 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  allows legislative history to be consulted “cautiously” at step one of Chevron analysis but 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  precludes its use to “enforce a principle…that has no statutory reference point.” United Cook Inlet 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Drift Ass’n v. Nat’l Marine Fisheries Serv., 837 F.3d 1055, 1063 n.1 (9th Cir. 2016) (internal 
19  citations and quotations omitted). One cited portion of the legislative history indicates section 
20  12184(b), generally, applies to individuals with mobility impairments. H.R. Rep. No. 101-336, at 
21  401 (1990). It does not, however, specifically discuss the “auxiliary aids and services” 
22  requirement. Another cited provision clarifies that the examples provided in section 12103(1) are 
23  just examples, not an exhaustive list of “auxiliary aids and services.” Id. at 161. Again, however, 
24  that does not clarify how far past the list the term does extend. The final cited provision is perhaps 
25  plaintiffs’ best case: it uses the example of how a bookstore must be made accessible to 
26  wheelchair-bound individuals in the context of defining “auxiliary aids and services.” Id. at 161–
27  62. However, even this piece of history does not go so far as to state affirmatively that “auxiliary 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
10 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 11 of 12
 
1  aids and services” are not limited to hearing- and vision-impaired individuals. It is hardly “clear 
2  evidence” which “illuminate[s] ambiguous text.” Milner v. Dep’t of Navy, 562 U.S. 562, 572 
3  (2011). See also Azar v. Allina Health Servs., 139 S. Ct. 1804, 1814 (2019) (declining to follow 
4  legislative history which was “ambiguous at best”). Thus, congressional intent is not clear. 
5  Moving on to Chevron step two, the DOJ Rule must be deferred to unless it is 
6  unreasonable. The Rule clearly provides that the provisions of the ADA encompassing “auxiliary 
7  aids and services” do not apply to individuals with mobility impairments because they are covered 
8  by other parts of the ADA, such as reasonable modifications. See DOJ Rule. Because the ADA 
9  requires “auxiliary aids and services” to be offered proactively, while “reasonable modifications” 
10  must be requested, plaintiffs point out the DOJ Rule creates two types of disabilities: those that 
11  must be affirmatively accommodated (hearing and vision impairments), and those that need not be 
12  accommodated absent a request (all other disabilities). While this system may not be what 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  plaintiffs prefer, “or even the reading the court would have reached if the question initially had 
Cif
t al
cC 14  arisen in a judicial proceeding,” Chevron, 467 U.S. at 843 n.11, plaintiffs have not explained how 
i
strof 
Dict  15  it is unreasonable. The DOJ might reasonably have considered, for example, that those who suffer 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  from hearing and vision impairments may have more difficulty even communicating their need for 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  an accommodation than those with other disabilities. It seems the DOJ simply chose “among 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  competing reasonable interpretations” of the ADA. Michigan v. E.P.A., 135 S. Ct. 2699, 2708 
19  (2015). The courts have no authority to second-guess it. Thus plaintiffs, as a matter of law, cannot 
20  plausibly allege an “auxiliary aids and services” claim. 
21  Finally, defendants argue plaintiffs have failed to allege plausibly a failure to remove 
22  barriers, 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2)(C), or a failure to communicate, 49 C.F.R. § 37.167(f). Plaintiffs 
23  did not respond to those arguments. Furthermore, when defendants’ reply indicated they 
24  considered plaintiffs’ nonresponses to amount to forfeiture of the arguments, plaintiffs did not 
25  move to clarify if they did not intend to do so. Plaintiffs’ theories regarding failure to remove 
26  barriers and failure to communicate are therefore dismissed. See Ardente, Inc. v. Shanley, No. 07-
27  cv-04479, 2010 WL 546485, at *6 (N.D. Cal. Feb. 10, 2010) (“Plaintiff fails to respond to this 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
11 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 12 of 12
 
1  argument and therefore concedes it through silence.”). 
2  V.  CONCLUSION 
3    For the reasons set forth above, the motion to dismiss is granted in part and denied in part. 
4  Plaintiffs have plausibly alleged a private right of action and a requested reasonable modification. 
5  However, they cannot plausibly allege a failure to provide auxiliary aids and have failed to 
6  respond to defendants’ arguments regarding a failure to remove barriers or to communicate. Those 
7  theories are therefore dismissed with prejudice. With these modifications, the SAC shall proceed 
8  as the operative complaint. 
9   
10  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
11   
12  Dated: March 12, 2020
