documents.title: Order on Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
documents.text:
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6   
7  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
9   
SCOTT CRAWFORD, et al.,
10  Case No. 17-cv-02664-RS   
Plaintiffs,   
11   
v.  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND 
a  12    GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR 
rt ni UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC., et al.,  JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
ur
oo 13 
t Calif Defendants.   
cC 14 
striof     
Dict  15   
s ri
et
tatDis 16  I. INTRODUCTION 
S 
d rn
ee 17  Scott Crawford and Jarvis Jernigan bring this action against Uber Technologies, Inc. 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  (Uber) and its subsidiary Raiser, LLC for failure to make reasonable accommodations under 
19  federal and California state disability law. After answering the complaint, Uber moved for 
20  judgment on the pleadings, arguing that plaintiffs lack standing to bring their claims, the relevant 
21  ADA provisions do not apply to Uber, and the relevant California state law provisions cannot 
22  regulate conduct that occurs solely outside of California. Pursuant to Civil Local Rule 7-1(b), the 
23  motion is suitable for disposition without oral argument. For the reasons set forth below, the 
24  motion is denied as to plaintiffs’ federal claims, but granted as to their California state law claims. 
25  II. BACKGROUND 
26  Uber operates a ride-for-hire service that utilizes a mobile phone app to connect riders with 
27  drivers who have signed up with the app. Uber app users can request and pay for a ride or other 
28  service through their credit card linked Uber account. On occasion, Uber offers short-term 

 
1  promotions that allow app users to order special sale items by clicking on an icon that appears in 
2  the user’s app for the duration of the promotion. When the promotion is over, the special icon 
3  disappears and the app returns to its usual appearance.  
4  The Uber app offers users services that vary from locality to locality. In some cities, such 
5  as Portland, San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Washington, D.C., the app displays an icon called 
6  “Uber Access.” When a user taps on the icon, one of two options appear, “UberASSIST” or 
7  “UberWAV.” UberASSIST connects app users with specially trained drivers who will assist riders 
8  into vehicles and can accommodate folding wheelchairs, walkers, and scooters. UberWAV offers 
9  app users the option to call a wheelchair accessible vehicle.  Neither of these options is available 
10  to Uber app users in Jackson.  
11  Crawford and Jernigan are persons with disabilities who live in Jackson, Mississippi, and 
12  its surrounding suburbs. Both plaintiffs have multiple sclerosis and use wheelchairs for mobility. 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  Because neither can drive, Crawford and Jernigan rely on buses, taxis, and other services to get 
Cif
t al
cC 14  around the Jackson metro area. One service they cannot utilize is Uber’s ride-sharing service, 
striof 
Dict  15  which allows mobile phone app users to call a car to get from one place to another. Because the 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  Uber app in Jackson does not provide an option for riders to call a wheelchair-accessible vehicle, 
S 
d rn
ee 17  Crawford and Jernigan are unable to use the service. Accordingly, plaintiffs allege, Uber has 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  violated its obligations under the Americans with Disabilities Act (“ADA”), the California 
19  Disabled Persons Act (“CDPA”), and the California Unfair Competition law (“UCL”). 
20  Crawford and Jernigan have never downloaded the Uber app because they are aware that 
21  their electric wheelchairs cannot fit into a standard car. If Uber were to offer ride services that 
22  could accommodate electric wheelchairs, Crawford and Jernigan would use the Uber app. Because 
23  Uber could add a mechanism for connecting riders to wheelchair accessible vehicles but does not 
24  do so in Jackson, Crawford and Jernigan assert that Uber prevents drivers with such vehicles from 
25  offering those services to disabled persons. Crawford and Jernigan seek declaratory and injunctive 
26  relief under Title III of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12181 et seq., the CDPA, Cal. Civ. Code § 54.1 et 
27  seq., and the UCL, Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq. 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
2 

 
1  III. LEGAL STANDARD 
2  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(c) provides that “[a]fter the pleadings are closed–but 
3  early enough not to delay trial–a party may move for judgment on the pleadings.” A motion for 
4  judgment on the pleadings is “functionally identical” to a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for 
5  failure to state a claim. See Dworkin v. Hustler Magazine, Inc., 867 F.2d 1188, 1192 (9th Cir. 
6  1989). “Judgment on the pleadings is properly granted when there is no material fact in dispute, 
7  and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.” Fleming v. Picard, 581 F.3d 922, 
8  925 (9th Cir. 2009). When deciding a 12(c) motion, all material allegations in the complaint are 
9  accepted as true and construed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Turner v. 
10  Cook, 362 F.3d 1219, 1225 (9th Cir. 2004). 
11  IV. DISCUSSION 
12  A.  Standing 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  The United States Constitution restricts federal judicial power to the adjudication of 
Cif
t al
cC 14  “cases” or “controversies.” U.S. Const. art. III, § 2, cl. 1. Plaintiffs seeking to adjudicate their 
striof 
Dict  15  grievances in federal court must first demonstrate that they have standing to sue—“an essential 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  and unchanging part of the case-or-controversy requirement of Article III.” Lujan v. Defenders of 
S 
d rn
ee 17  Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992). To establish standing, a plaintiff must show (1) he or she has 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  suffered or is threatened with an injury that is both “concrete and particularized,” and “actual or 
19  imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical;” (2) there is a causal link between the injury and the 
20  conduct of which the plaintiff complains—that is, the injury is “fairly traceable” to the challenged 
21  conduct; and (3) the injury is “likely” to be “redressed by a favorable decision.” Bates v. United 
22  Parcel Serv., Inc., 511 F.3d 974, 985 (9th Cir. 2007) (quoting Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560–61).  
23  “The Supreme Court has instructed us to take a broad view of constitutional standing in 
24  civil rights cases, especially where, as under the ADA, private enforcement suits ‘are the primary 
25  method of obtaining compliance with the Act.’ ” Doran v. 7–Eleven, Inc., 524 F.3d 1034, 1039 
26  (9th Cir. 2008) (quoting Trafficante v. Metro. Life Ins. Co., 409 U.S. 205, 209 (1972)). The ADA 
27  provides that a plaintiff is entitled to bring an action to correct both barriers he actually 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
3 

 
1  encountered and those he was deterred from encountering. 42 U.S.C. § 12188(a)(1). A person with 
2  a disability is not required to “engage in a futile gesture if such person has actual notice that a 
3  person or organization covered by this subchapter does not intend to comply with its provisions.” 
4  Id.  
5   “For purposes of ruling on a motion to dismiss for want of standing, both the trial and 
6  reviewing courts must accept as true all material allegations of the complaint, and must construe 
7  the complaint in favor of the complaining party.” Warth v. Seldin, 422 U.S. 490, 501 (1975). “At 
8  the pleading stage, general factual allegations of injury resulting from the defendant's conduct may 
9  suffice” to establish a concrete injury. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. at 561. In addition, the 
10  plausibility determinations as required by “Twombly and Iqbal are ill-suited to application in the 
11  constitutional standing context” because “ ‘[t]he jurisdictional question of standing precedes, and 
12  does not require, analysis of the merits.’ ” Maya v. Centex Corp., 658 F.3d 1060, 1068 (9th Cir. 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  2011) (quoting Equity Lifestyle Props., Inc. v. Cnty. of San Luis Obispo, 548 F.3d 1184, 1189 n.10 
Cif
t al
cC 14  (9th Cir. 2008)). 
striof 
Dict  15  Uber argues that Crawford and Jernigan lack standing to seek injunctive relief because 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  they cannot establish injury in fact or that their requested remedy will redress that injury. 
S 
d rn
ee 17  According to Uber, plaintiffs’ alleged injury—being denied access to Uber’s service—is 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  insufficiently concrete because they have never downloaded the Uber app and do not plausibly 
19  allege that they were deterred from doing so. This argument is unpersuasive. As Uber 
20  acknowledges, under Ninth Circuit precedent, plaintiffs suing under Title III are not required to 
21  engage in a “futile gesture” in order to show actual injury under the ADA. See Pickern v. Holiday 
22  Quality Foods Inc., 293 F.3d 1133, 1136-37 (9th Cir. 2002). In Civil Rights Education & 
23  Enforcement Center v. Hospitality Properties Trust, 867 F.3d 1093 (9th Cir. 2017), the Ninth 
24  Circuit explicitly rejected the requirement that ADA plaintiffs “personally encounter” barriers in 
25  order to have standing. 867 F.3d at 1099. Plaintiffs who had telephoned hotels to inquire about 
26  transportation services available to disabled guests sufficiently alleged that they were deterred 
27  from patronizing those establishments until barriers to access were removed. See id. (It is the 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
4 

 
1  plaintiff’s “actual knowledge” of a barrier, rather than its source, that is determinative.).  
2  Nonetheless, Uber contends that plaintiffs have not offered specific facts sufficient to make 
3  their conclusory allegations of deterrence plausibly genuine and concrete. According to Uber, 
4  plaintiffs cannot establish injury because they do not allege possession of the equipment, accounts, 
5  and payment methods necessary to create an Uber account, and do not describe specific moments 
6  when they were deterred from using the service or when they will do so in the future. The ADA 
7  does not place such heavy pleading burdens on persons seeking to remove barriers to access. 
8  Crawford and Jernigan state they have actual knowledge that the Uber app in Mississippi does not 
9  have a mechanism for summoning a WAV vehicle, which precludes them from using the 
10  transportation services the app facilitates. Thus, they are deterred from downloading the Uber app. 
11  According to their complaint, Crawford and Jernigan “plan to and will attempt to use the Uber 
12  Application . . . in the future as patrons should those programs, services, and accommodations 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  become wheelchair-accessible.” Compl. at 6. At the pleading stage, plaintiffs are not required to 
Cif
t al
cC 14  do more to demonstrate a concrete and imminent injury under the ADA. 
striof 
Dict  15  Even if plaintiffs can show concrete injury, Uber contends that a favorable ruling on their 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  request for injunctive relief will not redress that injury. Uber points out, and plaintiffs do not 
S 
d rn
ee 17  dispute, that it is a private entity that may not be ordered to purchase WAV vehicles. Because 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Uber does not currently own the cars used by Uber drivers, an injunction requiring them to acquire 
19  WAV vehicles would, according to Uber, impermissibly compel a fundamental alteration to the 
20  nature of its business. An alternative injunction requiring Uber merely to modify the Uber app to 
21  include UberASSIST and UberWAV options would also be problematic, Uber argues, because the 
22  modification could not ensure that any drivers participate in either service. Should Uber be 
23  required to use monetary or other incentives to encourage drivers to participate in UberASSIST 
24  and UberWAV programs, the drivers themselves retain “broad and legitimate discretion” 
25  regarding the choice to convert their personal vehicles into WAVs or undergo training to work 
26  with UberASSIST. Therefore, Uber concludes, plaintiffs fail to establish redressability because the 
27  prospective benefits of their requested remedy turn on the independent decisions of third party 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
5 

 
1  drivers. See Glanton ex. Rel. ALCOA Prescription Drug Plan v. AdvancePCS Inc., 465 F.3d 1123, 
2  1125 (9th Cir. 2006).  
3  Once again, Uber’s arguments are unpersuasive. Whether drivers exercise the degree of 
4  independence described by Uber is a question of fact that cannot be determined on the pleadings 
5  alone. For example, if further factual development demonstrates that drivers must satisfy certain 
6  requirements in order to sign up on the Uber app, or that drivers must conduct rides in a manner 
7  prescribed by Uber, that would undercut Uber’s view that injunctive relief is entirely dependent on 
8  drivers’ choices. For example, on the present record there is no reason to believe that Uber could 
9  not institute possession of a WAV as a prerequisite for drivers who wish to provide rides through 
10  the app. Such a modification to Uber’s policies would arguably redress plaintiffs’ alleged injury. 
11  Nor is it possible to determine conclusively that there are no other reasonable modification options 
12  available that would enable Uber to meet the requirements of the ADA. Plaintiffs request 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  “injunctive relief to require Defendants to bring their transportation service into compliance and 
Cif
t al
cC 14  remain in compliance with state and federal anti-discrimination statutes.” Compl. at 18. Uber 
striof 
Dict  15  points to no authority indicating that plaintiffs are required to allege the precise means of redress 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  at the pleading stage. Here, plaintiffs plausibly state a claim for relief that is not beyond the power 
S 
d rn
ee 17  of the Court to address. Accordingly, Uber’s motion for judgment on the pleadings for lack of 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  standing is denied. 
19  B.  Applicability of the ADA 
20  Should plaintiffs have standing to assert their claims, Uber argues that judgment on the 
21  pleadings is warranted on the grounds that Uber is not a covered entity under 42 U.S.C. § 12184.1 
22  This section, Uber reasons, is inapplicable because Uber is not an entity “primarily engaged in the 
23  business of transporting people.” 42 C.F.R. § 37.29. Uber views itself as a technology company 
24  that is engaged in the business of facilitating networking between drivers and riders. Because Uber 
25 
                                                 
26  1 Although Uber also asserts that it is not a covered entity under Section 12182, plaintiffs deny 
asserting a claim under that section and will be held to that representation. Thus, Uber’s arguments 
27  on that point need not be addressed.  
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
6 

 
1  does not own its own vehicles or lease them to Uber drivers, it believes it cannot be categorized as 
2  a taxi service under Section 12184. According to Uber, the service it offers is akin to that provided 
3  by expedia.com, a website through which individuals can book rooms at third-party hotels. In the 
4  recent opinion, the Seventh Circuit held that the operators of expedia.com were not “engaged in 
5  the business of renting hotel rooms” because they lacked ownership of the hotel rooms or 
6  independent power to grant possession. See Village of Bedford Park v. Expedia, Inc., 876 F.3d 
7  296, 299-300 (7th Cir. 2017). In Uber’s view, no factual development is necessary because 
8  plaintiffs admit that drivers, rather than Uber, convey passengers in vehicles not owned by Uber.  
9  These arguments miss the mark. First, nothing in Section 12184 requires that an entity own 
10  or lease its own vehicles in order to qualify as a private entity providing taxi service within the 
11  meaning of the statute. Second, whether Uber exerts sufficient control over its drivers such that 
12  drivers operate as an extension of Uber when they transport riders is a mixed question of law and 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  fact that cannot be determined on the pleadings. Setting aside the need for further factual 
Cif
t al
cC 14  development, Uber’s analogy to expedia.com is a strained one. Expedia facilitates a transaction 
striof 
Dict  15  that is not dependent on the service it offers. Hotels have rented rooms to guests long before the 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  creation of expedia.com, and can do so without the website’s assistance. By contrast, without Uber 
S 
d rn
ee 17  and its competitors, non-professional drivers would find it difficult—if not impossible—to locate a 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  rider and transport her to the destination of her choice for monetary compensation. To say that 
19  Uber merely facilitates connections between “both sides of the two-sided ridesharing market” 
20  obscures the fact that Uber arguably created a market for this type of transportation. While 
21  Expedia does not exercise control over how hotels listed on its website price their rooms or deal 
22  with hotel guests, whether the same can be said of Uber’s relationship to its drivers is not clear 
23  from the pleadings alone. In at least one case in this district, a court determined that there were 
24  significant factual questions as to Uber’s degree of control over its drivers for employment law 
25  purposes, precluding summary judgment before trial. See O’Conner v. Uber Technologies, Inc., 82 
26  F. Supp. 3d 1133 (N.D. Cal. 2015). Here, because plaintiffs have plausibly alleged that Uber is 
27  “primarily engaged in the business of transporting people” within the meaning of Section 12184, 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
7 

 
1  Uber cannot defeat ADA liability on the grounds that it is not a covered entity. 
2  Nonetheless, Uber insists that plaintiffs cannot proceed under the ADA because Section 
3  12184 does not require private entities providing taxi service to furnish WAV service or acquire 
4  WAV vehicles. Focusing on Sections 12184(b)(3) and (b)(5), Uber rejects plaintiffs’ assertion that 
5  a covered entity has only two choices: purchase accessible vehicles or provide equivalent service. 
6  On the contrary, an entity may maintain a fleet of exclusively non-accessible vehicles without 
7  violating the ADA. Uber’s fixation on whether WAVs are specifically required by statute is 
8  unavailing in light of the broad language of the ADA. A covered entity under Section 12184 is 
9  subject not just to the narrow requirements associated with the purchase of new vehicles, but the 
10  statute’s broader anti-discrimination mandate. Included in that mandate is an affirmative 
11  obligation to make reasonable accommodations, to provide auxiliary aides and services, and 
12  remove barriers to access. See 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2). Uber could very well be required to 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  provide WAV service through some mechanism in order to comply with the anti-discrimination 
Cif
t al
cC 14  provisions of Section 12184(b)(2). Whether providing WAV service will “fundamentally alter” the 
striof 
Dict  15  nature of Uber’s business is a question of fact that cannot be resolved on the pleadings. Therefore, 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  Uber’s motion for judgment on the pleadings as to plaintiffs’ ADA claims is denied. 
S 
d rn
ee 17  C.  State Law Protections for Out-of-State Plaintiffs 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  With respect to plaintiffs’ state law claims, Uber asserts the CDPA does not protect 
19  Mississippi plaintiffs whose alleged harm occurred outside of California. Crawford and Jernigan 
20  disagree, arguing they were injured by the decisions that were made at Uber’s headquarters in 
21  California.  
22  California has a strong presumption against extraterritorial application of its laws. North 
23  Alaskan Salmon Co. v. Pillsbury, 174 Cal. 1, 4 (1916). “The intention to make the act operative 
24  with respect to occurrences outside the state will not be declared to exist unless such intention is 
25  clearly expressed or reasonably to be inferred from the language of the act or from its purpose, 
26  subject-matter, or history.” Id. (internal quotations omitted). The CDPA contains no language that 
27  indicates its protections should be extended to individuals in other states, for injuries that took 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
8 

 
1  place outside of California. See Sousanis v. Northwest Airlines, Inc. et al., 2000 WL 34015861 at 
2  7 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 3, 2000) (concluding that “[t]here is no reason to infer from the language or 
3  purpose of Civil Code section 54.1 that it is meant to prohibit discrimination against individuals 
4  outside of California.”). Indeed, because other states have their own disability rights laws, the 
5  basic principles of federalism prevent the extension of the California protections to people who do 
6  not live in California and have not suffered harm in the state.    
7  Plaintiffs contend they were injured in California because the corporate decision to make 
8  the Uber app inaccessible to Mississippi wheelchair users took place at Uber headquarters in San 
9  Francisco. Although plaintiffs’ theory of liability supported denial of Uber’s motion to transfer 
10  venue from its home jurisdiction to Mississippi, the mere existence of a corporate decision in 
11  California that ultimately impacts an individual outside of California does not necessarily mean 
12  the individual was “injured” in California. The crux of plaintiffs’ claim is that the Jackson, 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  Mississippi, version of Uber’s product is deficient as compared to the San Francisco, California, 
Cif
t al
cC 14  version, which has accessible options. Thus, the alleged discrimination in this case occurred in 
striof 
Dict  15  Mississippi, where Crawford and Jernigan claim they were denied access to Uber’s transportation 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  services. Plaintiffs fail to point to any evidence from the CDPA’s statutory language, 
S 
d rn
ee 17  implementing regulations, or legislative history that supports the notion that plaintiffs who use or 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  desire to use Uber in another state may sue Uber under California’s disability law as long as the 
19  alleged harm was in some way traceable back to Uber headquarters. Therefore, Uber’s motion for 
20  judgment on the pleadings is granted with respect to plaintiffs’ CDPA claims.  
21  Plaintiffs’ remaining state law claim under the UCL is predicated on their ADA claim, 
22  which survives judgment on the pleadings. Yet as with the CDPA claim, plaintiffs cannot point to 
23  any evidence showing that the UCL authorizes the regulation of business activities occurring 
24  outside the state of California and affecting only non-California residents. See Sullivan v. Oracle 
25  Corp., 51 Cal. 4th 1191, 1207 (2011) (“Neither the language of the UCL nor its legislative history 
26  provides any basis for concluding the Legislature intended the UCL to operate extraterritorially.”). 
27  Because plaintiffs’ claims are rooted in Uber’s alleged denial of reasonable accommodation, 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
CASE NO. 17-cv-02664-RS 
9 

 
1  which took place in Mississippi, the challenged conduct is beyond the reach of the UCL. 
2  Accordingly, Uber’s motion for judgment on the pleadings as to plaintiffs’ UCL claim is granted. 
3  V. CONCLUSION 
4  For the reasons explained above, Uber’s motion for judgment on the pleadings is denied as 
5  to plaintiffs’ ADA claims and granted as to their claims under the CDPA and the UCL. 
6  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
7   
8  Dated: March 1, 2018

RICHARD SEEBORG

N 18  UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC., et al.,  SUMMARY JUDGMENT; DENYING 
MOTIONS IN LIMINE AND MOTION 
19  Defendants.  TO STRIKE 
20     
 
21  I. INTRODUCTION 
22  Plaintiffs are three people using motorized wheelchairs who asked Defendants Uber 
23  Technologies, Inc. and its subsidiary Rasier, Inc. (collectively “Defendants” or “Uber”) to provide 
24  wheelchair-accessible vehicle (“WAV”) service (“UberWAV”) in their home cities of New 
25  Orleans, Louisiana and Jackson, Mississippi. After Uber declined, Plaintiffs brought this suit 
26  accusing Uber of violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (“ADA”). Both parties now move 
27  for summary judgment. Because many material facts remain in dispute, neither party is entitled to 
28  summary judgment at this juncture. Both motions are therefore granted in part and denied in part. 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 2 of 25
 
1  Both motions in limine and the motion to strike are also denied.  
2  II. BACKGROUND 
3  Uber operates a ride-for-hire service that utilizes a mobile phone app to connect riders with 
4  drivers who have signed up with the app. The most popular type of ride is UberX, where drivers 
5  provide trips in standard, four-door vehicles. Many drivers offer rides in their own, personal cars 
6  resulting in a robust supply of UberX drivers, but these services vary from locality to locality. In 
7  some cities, such as Portland, San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Washington, D.C., the app 
8  includes “UberWAV,” which offers app users the option to call a WAV. This option is not 
9  available to Uber app users in New Orleans or Jackson.  
10  Scott Crawford, Stephan Namisnak, and Francis Falls (hereinafter, “Plaintiffs”) are persons 
11  who use electric wheelchairs. Crawford lives in Jackson, Mississippi while Namisnak and Falls 
12  live in New Orleans, Louisiana. None of the Plaintiffs have downloaded the Uber app, but have all 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  declared under oath that if Uber were to offer ride services that could accommodate electric 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  wheelchairs, they would use them. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  III. LEGAL STANDARD 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Summary judgment is proper “if the movant shows that there is no genuine dispute as to 
S d nr
ee 17  any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a). 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  The purpose of summary judgment “is to isolate and dispose of factually unsupported claims or 
19  defenses.” Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323–24 (1986). The moving party “always 
20  bears the initial responsibility of informing the district court of the basis for its motion, and 
21  identifying those portions of the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
22  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, which it believes demonstrate the absence of a genuine 
23  issue of material fact.” Id. at 323 (internal quotation marks omitted). If it meets this burden, the 
24  moving party is then entitled to judgment as a matter of law when the non-moving party fails to 
25  make a sufficient showing on an essential element of the case with respect to which it bears the 
26  burden of proof at trial. Id. at 322–23. 
27    To preclude the entry of summary judgment, the non-moving party must bring forth 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
2 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 3 of 25
 
1  material facts, i.e., “facts that might affect the outcome of the suit under the governing law[.]” 
2  Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986). The opposing party “must do more 
3  than simply show that there is some metaphysical doubt as to the material facts.” Matsushita Elec. 
4  Indus. Co., Ltd. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574, 586 (1986). The trial court must “draw all 
5  justifiable inferences in favor of the nonmoving party, including questions of credibility and of the 
6  weight to be accorded particular evidence.” Masson v. New Yorker Magazine, Inc., 501 U.S. 496, 
7  520 (1991). The court must then “determine whether the ‘specific facts’ set forth by the 
8  nonmoving party, coupled with undisputed background or contextual facts, are such that a rational 
9  or reasonable jury might return a verdict in its favor based on that evidence.” T.W. Elec. Serv., Inc. 
10  v. Pacific Elec. Contractors Ass’n, 809 F.2d 626, 631 (9th Cir. 1987).  
11  IV. DISCUSISON 
12  A.  Cross Motions for Summary Judgment  
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Plaintiffs move for summary judgment alleging Uber is subject to Title III of the ADA 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  because it is a “private entity that is primarily engaged in the business of transporting people and 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  whose operations affect commerce.” 42 U.S.C. § 12184(a). Second, they seek a determination that 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Uber must “provide WAV service” in Jackson and New Orleans. Uber cross-moves, arguing (1) 
S d nr
ee 17  Plaintiffs lack standing because they did not download the Uber app, (2) it is not a transportation 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  company subject to the ADA, (3) the ADA does not require the provision of WAV service as a 
19  matter of law, and (4) Plaintiffs cannot prove at trial that their requested outcomes are reasonable.  
20  1.  Standing 
21  Standing to pursue injunctive relief requires injury-in-fact, including a “real and immediate 
22  threat of repeated injury in the future.” Chapman v. Pier 1 Imports (U.S.) Inc., 631 F.3d 939, 946 
23  (9th Cir. 2011) (en banc). However, at the summary judgment stage, plaintiffs need only show 
24  “there is a genuine question of material fact as to the standing elements.” Truth v. Kent Sch. Dist., 
25  524 F.3d 957, 965 (9th Cir. 2008). Under the Ninth Circuit’s “deterrent effect doctrine,” a plaintiff 
26  has the requisite injury if “the plaintiff was deterred from attempting to visit a location or use a 
27  service because of alleged ADA noncompliance.” Namisnak v. Uber Techs., Inc., 971 F.3d 1088, 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
3 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 4 of 25
 
1  1092 (9th Cir. 2020). To demonstrate this deterrence, a plaintiff must show that attempting to visit 
2  the location or use the service is a “futile gesture,” id., and that the plaintiff intends to patronize 
3  the defendant’s business once the alleged noncompliance has been removed, Chapman, 631 F.3d 
4  at 949–50. 
5  Uber’s standing argument is arguably foreclosed by the Ninth Circuit’s affirmance of this 
6  Court’s previous conclusion at the pleading stage that Namisnak and Falls could satisfy the injury-
7  in-fact prong via the “futile gesture” doctrine. See Namisnak, 971 F.3d at 1093–94. In fact, the 
8  Ninth Circuit specifically noted that Plaintiffs alleged they were aware that Uber does not offer 
9  UberWAV in New Orleans, that they cannot use Uber because of this failure, that they plan to use 
10  the app if it offers accessible rides, and that they feared they would encounter mobility-related 
11  barriers were they to attempt to use Uber. Id. Because Plaintiffs had actual knowledge that Uber 
12  did not provide UberWAV in New Orleans, “[t]hat barrier to entry makes downloading the Uber 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  App and creating an account a futile gesture.” Id. at 1094. In coming to that conclusion, the Ninth 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Circuit specifically rejected Uber’s invitation to follow a line of Seventh Circuit cases holding that 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  attempting to use Uber was not a “futile gesture” for disabled plaintiffs in Chicago because the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Uber app in that city included a WAV request option. Id. (referring to Access Living v. Uber 
S d nr
ee 17  Techs., Inc., 958 F.3d 604, 614 (7th Cir. 2020)). The cases were distinguishable specifically 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  because Uber does not offer UberWAV in New Orleans. Id.  
19  Uber nonetheless urges a reconsideration of Namisnak based on a subsequent Supreme 
20  Court ruling, Carney v. Adams, 141 S.Ct. 493 (2020). In that case, Adams challenged Delaware’s 
21  eligibility requirements for judicial office. Id. at 497. The Court held that his mere assertion that 
22  applying for a judgeship was futile did not demonstrate injury-in-fact unless Adams was “able and 
23  ready” to apply. Id. at 500. Adams’ testimony that he “would apply” was on its own insufficient; 
24  the Court searched the record fruitlessly for another indication that his “intent” to apply was 
25  “concrete.” Id. at 501–02.  
26  Attempting to shoehorn those general findings into the specifics of this case, Uber argues 
27  that Plaintiffs’ professed intent to use the Uber app, “without more and against all contrary 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
4 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 5 of 25
 
1  evidence” cannot confer standing. See id. at 501. In support, it aggregates facts it believes 
2  contradicts Plaintiffs’ stated intent to use the Uber app. Namisnak traveled to San Francisco, 
3  which he knew offered UberWAV, but chose to use a taxicab instead. He traveled mostly by bus 
4  and, at the end of his trip, used Lyft to call a standard vehicle, rather than a WAV, to the airport. 
5  He often travels to the airport using a folding wheelchair in a standard car and relying on the help 
6  of those who know how to help him enter and exit a standard car. Uber alleges he has not used for-
7  hire transportation in and around New Orleans since 2010. Next, Uber asserts Crawford declined 
8  to use UberWAV even in Washington, D.C., where it is offered, invoking his statement that he did 
9  not check to see if UberWAV was available because there was a large supply of accessible taxis. 
10  He further claimed he did not need UberWAV because taxis worked. He admitted, in relation to a 
11  trip to San Francisco, that he preferred public transit if available. Lastly, Uber alleges Falls has 
12  never hired a WAV; the only accessible transportation he uses is the bus. He admitted at a 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  deposition that he did not know whether there were providers of for-hire WAV services in New 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Orleans. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  At a basic level, the facts here are distinguishable from Carney, which operated largely as 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  an experiment. Adams became interested in the issue of Delaware’s qualification scheme (which 
S d nr
ee 17  prohibits Independents from applying for judgeships) after reading about it in a law review. Id. at 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  500–01. He shortly thereafter registered as an Independent and eight days later filed suit. Id. The 
19  Supreme Court’s probe beyond Adams’ apparently insincere assertion that he intended to apply 
20  for a judgeship focuses on the disingenuous nature of his assertion. There is no reason to believe 
21  Plaintiffs are similarly simply testing the legal waters.  
22  Even if Uber is correct that there is some relevance to Plaintiffs’ decision not to use 
23  UberWAV when it was available to them in other cities, Uber’s emphasis on cherry-picked 
24  incidents in which Plaintiffs relied on other forms of transportation is not convincing because it 
25  fails to grapple with relevant context. For instance, on his trip to San Francisco, Namisnak left 
26  transportation accommodation to his wife, so the decision to take a taxicab or standard Lyft, rather 
27  than an Uber, was not his. More broadly, Plaintiffs’ decision to rely on transportation methods 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
5 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 6 of 25
 
1  with which they appear to be institutionally familiar does not contradict their stated interest in 
2  using an UberWAV in New Orleans. Crawford preferred a taxi in Washington D.C. because he 
3  prefers to “keep it simple and use the taxis cause [he] know[s] it works,” whereas there are few 
4  accessible taxis in his hometown of Jackson. Opposition (“Opp.”) to Defendants’ Motion for 
5  Summary Judgment (“DSJ”) Ex. RRR at 32. He would therefore welcome the opportunity to use 
6  another form of accessible transportation when he needs to get somewhere quickly and suddenly. 
7  Lastly, Falls recalls a specific incident in which he was out with friends and could not locate an 
8  accessible vehicle at the end of the night. Falls attempted to roll himself home and was hit by a 
9  car. Needless to say, Falls is likely to make use of on-demand WAV transport, just as he claimed 
10  in his deposition.1 Uber’s proffered bits of the record do not defeat a finding that Plaintiffs have 
11  standing.  
12  2.  ADA Claims 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Under Title III of the ADA, “[n]o individual shall be discriminated against on the basis of 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  disability in the full and equal enjoyment of specified public transportation services provided by a 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  private entity that is primarily engaged in the business of transporting people and whose 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  operations affect commerce.” 42 U.S.C. § 12184(a). Plaintiffs bring claims under three 
S d nr
ee 17  subsections of § 12184. First, they allege Uber imposed “eligibility criteria that screen[ed] out or 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  tend[ed] to screen out an individual with a disability or [a] class of individuals with disabilities 
19  from fully enjoying the specified public transportation services[.]” Id. § 12184(b)(1). Second, they 
20  contend Uber has purchased “a new van . . . that is not readily accessible to or usable by 
21  individuals with disabilities” without providing “a level of service to such individuals equivalent 
22  to the level of service provided to the general public.” Id. § 12184(b)(5). Third, they claim Uber 
23  failed to “make reasonable modifications consistent with those required under section 
24  12182(b)(2)(A)(ii).” Id. § 12184(b)(2)(A). Section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii) defines as discrimination the 
25 
 
26  1 Uber’s argument that Falls lost standing during the litigation because he was “totally bedbound” 
after a hospitalization and therefore could not have used a WAV because he would have required a 
27  vehicle that could accommodate a stretcher is not compelling. DSJ at 9. 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
6 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 7 of 25
 
1  “failure to make reasonable modifications in policies, practices, or procedures, when such 
2  modifications are necessary . . . unless the entity can demonstrate that making such modifications 
3  would fundamentally alter the nature” of the goods or services provided. 
4  a.  Defendants are Covered Entities2 
5  In order to proceed under Title III, Plaintiffs must first establish Uber is an entity 
6  “primarily engaged in the business of transporting people and whose operations affect commerce.” 
7  42 U.S.C. § 12184(a). Plaintiffs contend Uber is a covered entity for four distinct reasons: (1) 
8  Uber publicly represents that it provides transportation, (2) Uber controls “virtually every aspect 
9  of its transportation system,” (3) Uber owns tens of thousands of vehicles used to transport riders, 
10  and (4) Title III attaches to entities providing transportation through third parties.3 Plaintiffs’ 
11  Motion for Summary Judgment (“PSJ”) at 14. In its own motion for summary judgment, Uber 
12  notes that this Court earlier characterized the issue of whether Uber exerts dispositive control over 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  its drivers as a mixed question of law and fact. While it does not concede it is a covered entity, it 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  acknowledges that its arguments on this point rely on facts that are in dispute and does not seek 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  summary judgment on this issue. In its opposition to Plaintiffs’ motion, however, it contends 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Plaintiffs have not carried their burden to show it is a covered entity. The gravamen of Uber’s 
S d nr
ee 17  opposition is its insistence that it sells technology, not transportation. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Though it considers the question in a different context, the court in O’Connor v. Uber 
19 
 
20 
2 At the outset, Defendants briefly contend Plaintiffs’ motion must be denied as to Rasier because 
21  their arguments are singularly focused on Uber. To grant the motion as to Rasier, they argue, 
would pierce the corporate veil without basis. Moreover, the failure to address Rasier on its own 
22  requires the denial of the motion also as to Uber because Rasier, not Uber, is the permitted 
transportation network company in the relevant cities and licenses the Uber Driver app to drivers. 
23  Uber is thus even further removed from passenger transportation than Rasier. In response, 
Plaintiffs clarify that all their briefing applies to both entities. Without more from Defendants 
24  explaining why Plaintiffs’ arguments cannot be applied to both entities, or how Rasier’s business 
differs from Uber’s, there is no basis to conclude Rasier is categorically immune from Plaintiffs’ 
25  arguments aimed at both entities.  
26  3 Though Uber dedicates a large portion of its opposition to combatting the proposition that it 
“stands in the shoes” of its drivers, this theory is not discussed because Uber is a covered entity in 
27  its own right.  
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
7 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 8 of 25
 
1  Technologies, Inc. thoroughly considered and rejected the same argument Uber puts forth here. 82 
2  F.Supp.3d 1133, 1141–42 (N.D. Cal. 2015). Namely, that it is a “technology company” that ought 
3  not be subject to regulations aimed at a “transportation company.” There, Uber’s framing of the 
4  technology versus transportation question turned on the mechanics of its platform, an “unduly 
5  narrow” basis on which to judge the content of its business. Id. at 1141. As O’Connor observed, if 
6  Uber is a technology company, so must be Yellow Cab, which uses radio technology to dispatch 
7  its taxis, and John Deere, which uses robots to manufacture lawn mowers. Id. If, under Uber’s 
8  definition, “one focuses solely on how [entities] create or distribute their products,” nearly all 
9  companies would be technology companies. Id. Though Uber has, obviously, supplied the method 
10  by which drivers and passengers connect, it is undeniable that “Uber does not simply sell 
11  software; it sells rides.” Id. Uber’s theory that merely “provid[ing] technology and services to 
12  people who are engaged in the business of transporting people” does not make it “so engaged” is 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  therefore unpersuasive. Opposition to PSJ at 31.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Uber makes no compelling argument against this conclusion. Instead, it mainly asserts that 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  the question ought not be called at this stage because it disputes the facts underlying the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  contentions that it advertises itself as a transportation system and exercises control over its drivers. 
S d nr
ee 17  Yet Uber does not appear to contest the facts Plaintiffs put forth on either point. First, Plaintiffs 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  list many of the public and private places in which Uber refers to itself as a transportation 
19  company. An older mission statement explained Uber endeavored to “make transportation as 
20  reliable as running water everywhere, for everyone.” PSJ Ex. R. In various posts on its website, it 
21  boasts about improving the transportation systems of various cities: “Uber is not only transporting 
22  people, but increasing the number of residents small businesses can serve in all areas of 
23  Columbus.”; “We’re finally giving [Mexico City] the transportation system that it deserves.”;; 
24  “[W]e’re SO pumped to be providing [New Orleans] with reliable, safe, and convenient 
25  transportation…finally!”. PSJ Exs. V, Y, BB (ellipses in original). After the rollout of Uber LA, 
26  Uber’s then-CEO declared: “[I]t is today that Uber LA is officially rolling out its transportation

ee 17  Uber’s 30(b)(6) person most knowledgeable Niraj Patel, past experience shows incentives are 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  “largely ineffective at improving the reliability of the WAV marketplace.” Declaration of Niraj 
19  Patel (“Patel Decl.”) ¶ 75.10  
20  Third, Plaintiffs contemplate a return to a leasing model Uber used in the past. Under its 
21  agreement with subsidiary XL, XL would pay an auto manufacturer $43,000 for a WAV, which 
22  Uber would then lease to a driver, subsidizing part of the lease. Shortly before this suit was filed, 
23  Uber had a plan in place to add 800–1000 additional WAVs through “a combination of flexible 
24

10 Uber contradicts itself on this point. In its registration statement filed with the SEC, it explains

because it “can choose to use incentives, such as promotions for [d]rivers and consumers, to attract

1  leasing through a third party and [XL].” PSJ Ex. AAA. Before the plan was operationalized,

3  must be a reasonable solution. Though it would require upfront expenditure by Uber, those costs 
4  could be offset by the accessibility fee discussed above. To the extent it is not offset, Plaintiffs 
5  argue, Uber can likely bear the cost – Uber recently announced it was committing more than $800 
6  million to help drivers in the United States, Canada, and Europe transition to electric vehicles by

a

Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Plaintiffs propose. It follows that, at this stage, it is not feasible to determine as a matter of law

iD tc 15  whether Plaintiffs’ request is reasonable. Because the question must be put to a fact finder, both

et
tatsiD 16  motions for summary judgment are denied as to 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2).

ee 17  B.  Motions in Limine   
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Federal Rule of Evidence 702 provides that expert opinion testimony is admissible if: (1) 
19  the witness is qualified to testify about the topics to be addressed; (2) the expert’s specialized 
20  knowledge will help the jury “to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue”; (3) “the 
21  testimony is based on sufficient facts or data”; (4) “the testimony is the product of reliable 
22  principles and methods”; and (5) “the expert has reliably applied the principles and methods to the 
23  facts of the case.” The proponent of evidence bears the burden of establishing its admissibility. 
24  Bldg. Indus. Ass’n v. Wash. State Bldg. Code Council, 683 F.3d 1144, 1154 (9th Cir. 2012). 
25  1.  Motion to Exclude Testimony of Meera Joshi  
26  Plaintiffs have disclosed Meera Joshi, former Chair and CEO of the New York City Taxi 
27  and Limousine Commission (“TLC”) (currently the Deputy Administrator of the Federal Motor 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
20 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 21 of 25
 
1  Carrier Safety Administration in the Department of Transportation), as a non-retained expert. 
2  Plaintiffs indicate she will offer a range of opinions related to the transportation industry. Uber 
3  moves to exclude her as an expert, focusing on three of her opinions: (1) her opinion based on her 
4  time at the TLC that she “regarded” Uber as “in the business of transporting people for hire and 
5  regulated them in accordance with that opinion,” Declaration of Stephanie Schuster (“Schuster 
6  Decl.”) Ex. C at 46, (2) her opinion that Uber has the capacity to provide WAV service, and (3) 
7  her opinion that “Uber’s failure/refusal to provide WAV service stems from a desire to avoid the 
8  issue, not from an inability to provide said service,” Schuster Decl. Ex. A.  
9  Joshi’s opinions were solicited at her deposition which was taken by Plaintiffs, not Uber. 
10  At the deposition, Joshi confirmed that she did not review documents related to the case, did not 
11  know who the Plaintiffs were, and that she spent less than an hour preparing for the deposition. 
12  She also acknowledged she had no Jackson- or New Orleans-specific transportation expertise and 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  that her interactions with Uber were limited to its operations in New York City.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Uber explains why the three opinions highlighted above are inadmissible. First, it contends 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Joshi’s conclusion about Uber’s industry impermissibly passes on a matter of law: whether Uber is

et
tatsiD 16  “primarily engaged in the business of transporting people” and is thus subject to 42 U.S.C. § 
S d nr
ee 17  12184(a). Uber contends this alleged legal conclusion will impede the factfinder’s task by

27  the ADA is a question of law, Lopez v. Catalina Channel Express, Inc., 974 F.3d 1030, 1033 (9th 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
21

1  Cir. 2020), this Court earlier in this litigation concluded that a determination of whether Uber is

11  While Plaintiffs meet and exceed each of Uber’s arguments, they make the more incisive

a 
tr in
uoro 13  opinions she provided at her deposition. Though Uber’s first argument is presumably meant to

 tla

i
rts fo

et
tatsiD 16  or that her conclusion specifically uses ADA language. Joshi’s statement that she “regarded” Uber 
S d nr

Uo

23  2.  Motion to Exclude Testimony of Dr. James Cooper  
24  James Cooper, PhD is Plaintiffs’ retained expert. He has a doctorate in Taxi Licensing and 
25  Control from Edinburgh Napier University in Scotland. He is the director of Transport Research 
26  Partners and his research focuses on transportation operation and policy development, mostly 
27  abroad. Though Cooper’s expert report is hard to parse, he appears to conclude that Uber is a

1  “transport company” “subject to equality legislation, in this instance the Americans with

4  “infrastructure, potentially supply, and demand exist” in Jackson and New Orleans. Id. at 28. He 
5  finally states: “I conclude that the reasonable approach for Uber would indeed be to provide 
6  UberWAV in both cities.” Id. Uber points out Dr. Cooper does not define what it means to

9  It then distills Cooper’s report down to four opinions it believes Cooper may attempt to 
10  offer at trial: (1) Uber is a “transport company, being primarily engaged in the business of 
11  transporting people;” (2) Uber has a “duty to provide accessibility under the meanings of the 
12  [ADA]” and providing UberWAV in Jackson and New Orleans would not “fundamentally alter”

tr in
uoro 13  Uber’s services and any failure to comply “constitutes a breach of disability legislation;” (3) that a 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  supply of WAVs exist in both markets; and (4) that it would be a “reasonable approach” for Uber 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  to provide UberWAV in both cities. Id. at 25–26, 28. It essentially argues that because all four 
 sir
et

S d nr
ee 17  The parties make essentially the same arguments about Cooper as about Joshi. Uber 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  contends Cooper’s conclusions are impermissibly legal in nature or, as regards his third 
19  conclusion, irrelevant.11 While Plaintiffs acknowledge that, as enumerated, Cooper’s second 
20  conclusion would be an improper legal conclusion, they contend the first question is mixed and 
21  the question of reasonableness is ordinarily factual. See Sheehan v. City of S.F., 743 F.3d 1211, 
22  1233 (9th Cir. 2014) rev'd in part on other grounds. More importantly, they argue that all of 
23  Uber’s attacks on Cooper’s conclusions go to the weight his testimony should be afforded, not to 
24 
 
25  11 In its reply, Uber raises for the first time the idea that Cooper is inappropriately attempting to 
testify regarding facts about which he has no personal knowledge, such as Uber’s corporate 
26  structure, the way it sets fares, or its use of dynamic pricing. Even if these are determined to be 
facts requiring personal knowledge, Uber could object to those particular parts of his testimony as 
27  inadmissible. The proffer of these “facts” cannot lead to Cooper’s complete exclusion.  
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
23 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 24 of 25
 
1  whether he should be completely excluded as an expert. Again, Uber does not contend Cooper 
2  lacks the credentials, data, or reliable methods to arrive at his conclusions. The motion is therefore 
3  denied.  
4  C.  Motion to Strike  
5  Plaintiffs move to strike the testimony of Niraj Patel, Uber’s Director of Rider Operations 
6  for the United States and Canada designated as a lay witness, on the theory that his declaration in 
7  support of Uber’s motion for summary judgment contains expert, rather than lay, opinion. In his 
8  long declaration, Patel opines about drivers’ potential economic motivations, Uber’s potential 
9  future behavior or what would be rational for Uber to do, what riders and individuals with 
10  wheelchairs need, the potential effect of driver and rider behavior on the marketplace, and the 
11  effects various modifications would have on Uber’s business model and financial prospects. He 
12  has worked for Uber since 2014 and Uber alleges during that time he has personally viewed and 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  become familiar with the documents on which he relies and Uber’s business.   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Uber preliminarily contends that this type of “stand-alone objection[]” to evidence 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  submitted in support of a motion “[is] improper” under Civil Local Rule 7-3(a) and on that basis 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  should not be considered. See Salazar v. McDonald’s Corp., 2017 WL 88999, at *3 n.1 (N.D. Cal. 
S d nr
ee 17  Jan. 5, 2017). It also contends the appendix affixed to Plaintiffs’ motion is argumentative and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  should not be considered. Plaintiffs concede these points but urge consideration of their motion on 
19  the merits to determine whether Patel is permitted to offer his opinion testimony at trial.  
20  Though the motion will not be considered because it is indeed improper under Local Rule 
21  7-3, it must be noted that Patel’s declaration approaches the line separating lay and expert 
22  testimony. Many of his opinions are based in “specialized” economic and technical, rather than 
23  personal, knowledge. Furthermore, though he offers, for example, his opinion that a particular 
24  potential accommodation would “simply destroy ridesharing,” a conclusion predicated on Patel’s 
25  understanding of ridesharing economics and implementation, he provides no method by which to 
26  evaluate the opinion. Patel Decl. ¶ 37. On the other hand, as Uber points out, courts have 
27  distinguished “particularized knowledge that the witness has by virtue of his or her position in the 
28  ORDER 
CASE NOS.  17-cv-02664-RS; 17-cv-06124-RS 
24 

Case 3:17-cv-02664-RS   Document 197   Filed 08/26/21   Page 25 of 25
 
1  business” from the scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge contemplated by Federal 
2  Rules of Evidence 701 and 702. Open Text S.A. v. Box, Inc., 2015 WL 393858, at *7 (N.D. Cal. 
3  2015). Though Patel’s declaration will not be excluded at this time, this issue may be raised again 
4  at trial.  
5  V. CONCLUSION 
6    The questions these cross motions for summary judgment seek to resolve must be put to a 
7  fact finder. Accordingly, both motions are granted in part and denied in part. Both motions in 
8  limine and the motion to strike are denied.  
9   
10  IT IS SO ORDERED.

documents.title: Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Motion to Compel Arbitration
documents.text:
Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 1 of 7
 
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6   
7  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
9   
STEPHAN NAMISNAK, et al., 
10  Case No. 17-cv-06124-RS   
Plaintiffs,   
11   
v.  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND 
 a 12    DENYING IN PART MOTION TO 
 rtni UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC., et al.,  COMPEL ARBITRATION 
ouor 13 
t Calif Defendants.   
cC 14 
i
strof     
Dict  15   
s ri
et
tatDis 16  I. INTRODUCTION 
d Srn 
ee 17  Defendants Uber Technologies Inc. and Raiser, LLC (collectively “Uber”) move to compel 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  arbitration of all claims asserted by plaintiffs Stephan Namisnak, Francis Falls, and Mitchell 
19  Miraglia. Pursuant to Civil Local Rule 7-1(b), the motion is suitable for disposition without oral 
20  argument, and the hearing set for April 19, 2018, is vacated. For the reasons that follow, the 
21  motion is granted as to claims asserted by Miraglia and denied as to claims asserted by Namisnak 
22  and Falls.  
23  II. BACKGROUND 
24  Namisnak, Falls, and Miraglia are persons with disabilities who live in New Orleans, 
25  Louisiana. As a result of their physical limitations, they are dependent on electric wheelchairs for 
26  mobility. One service they cannot utilize is Uber’s ride-sharing service, which allows mobile 
27  phone app users to call a car to get from one place to another. Because the Uber App in New 
28  Orleans does not provide an option for riders to call a wheelchair-accessible vehicle, plaintiffs are 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 2 of 7
 
1  unable to use the service. Accordingly, plaintiffs allege, Uber has violated its obligations under the 
2  Americans with Disabilities Act (“ADA”), the California Disabled Persons Act (“CDPA”), and 
3  the California Unfair Competition law (“UCL”).  
4  When customers sign up to use Uber’s services, they must first create an account using the 
5  Uber App. The app user’s registration page displays the phrase, “by creating an uber account, you 
6  agree to our terms & conditions and privacy policy,” which is hyperlinked so the registrant may 
7  view the agreement. Creating an account requires the customer to accept Uber’s terms and 
8  conditions, including a mandatory arbitration provision.  
9  In 2016, Miraglia used a smartphone to access the Uber App and create a rider account. As 
10  part of the registration process, as described above, Miraglia was required to agree to Uber’s terms 
11  and conditions and privacy policy. Uber asserts that Miraglia is bound by the terms of that 
12  agreement and must submit his claims to arbitration pursuant to its arbitration provision.  
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  Falls and Namisnak never downloaded the Uber App or created an Uber account. As a 
Cif
t al
cC 14  consequence, neither plaintiff manifested agreement to Uber’s terms and conditions or had the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  opportunity to review any provisions contained therein. Nonetheless, Uber argues that because 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  plaintiffs rely upon Uber’s terms and conditions in bringing this action, they are equitably 
d Srn 
ee 17  estopped from challenging the agreement’s arbitration requirement.  
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  III. LEGAL STANDARD 
19  Uber’s terms and conditions agreement is “a contract evidencing a transaction involving 
20  commerce” subject to the Federal Arbitration Act (“FAA”). 9 U.S.C. § 2; Chiron Corp. v. Ortho 
21  Diagnostic Sys., Inc., 207 F.3d 1126, 1130 (9th Cir. 2000). “The FAA provides that any arbitration 
22  agreement within its scope ‘shall be valid, irrevocable, and enforceable,’ . . . and permits a party 
23  ‘aggrieved by the alleged . . . refusal of another to arbitrate’ to petition any federal district court 
24  for an order compelling arbitration in the manner provided for in the agreement.” Chiron, 207 
25  F.3d at 1130 (quoting 9 U.S.C. § 4) (second omission in original). The FAA “leaves no place for 
26  the exercise of discretion by a district court, but instead mandates that district courts shall direct 
27  the parties to proceed to arbitration on issues as to which an arbitration agreement has been 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
2 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 3 of 7
 
1  signed.” Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. v. Byrd, 470 U.S. 213, 218 (1985) (citing 9 U.S.C. §§ 3, 4). 
2  The role of a district court under the FAA “is therefore limited to determining (1) whether a valid 
3  agreement to arbitrate exists and, if it does, (2) whether the agreement encompasses the dispute at 
4  issue.” Chiron, 207 F.3d at 1130 (internal citations omitted). “If the response is affirmative on 
5  both counts, then the [FAA] requires the court to enforce the arbitration agreement in accordance 
6  with its terms.” Id. 
7  IV. DISCUSSION 
8  “Before a party to a lawsuit can be ordered to arbitrate . . . there should be an express, 
9  unequivocal agreement to that effect. Only when there is no genuine issue of fact concerning the 
10  formation of the agreement should the court decide as a matter of law that the parties did or did not 
11  enter into such an agreement.” Three Valleys Mun. Water Dist. v. E.F. Hutton & Co., 925 F.2d 1136, 
12  1141 (9th Cir. 1991) (internal quotations omitted). In deciding whether there is a genuine issue of fact 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  concerning formation of an agreement, the party opposing arbitration shall receive “the benefit of all 
Cif
t al
cC 14  reasonable doubts and inferences.” Id. (internal quotations omitted). “When deciding whether the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  parties agreed to arbitrate a certain matter . . . courts generally . . . should apply ordinary state-law 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  principles that govern the formation of contracts.” First Options of Chicago, Inc. v. Kaplan, 514 U.S. 
d Srn 
ee 17  938, 944 (1995). Under California law, mutual assent is the key to contract formation. See Binder v. 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Aetna Life Ins. Co., 75 Cal. App. 4th 832, 850 (Ct. App. 1999). In the context of an electronic 
19  consumer transaction, the occurrence of mutual assent ordinarily turns on whether the consumer had 
20  reasonable notice of a merchant’s terms of service agreement. See, e.g., Nguyen v. Barnes & Noble 
21  Inc., 763 F.3d 1171, 1173 (9th Cir. 2014) (“We agree with the district court that Barnes & Noble did 
22  not provide reasonable notice of its Terms of Use, and that Nguyen therefore did not unambiguously 
23  manifest assent to the arbitration provision contained therein.”). 
24  The parties do not dispute that the appearance of a terms and services link on the Uber App 
25  registration screen provided sufficient notice of the arbitration agreement. Rather, Namisnak and Falls 
26  deny being bound by an arbitration agreement to which they did not assent, seeing as neither plaintiff 
27  ever downloaded the Uber App or had the opportunity to review its terms and conditions. Miraglia 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
3 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 4 of 7
 
1  contends that although he initially agreed to Uber’s terms and conditions, the arbitration provision is 
2  unenforceable against him because he deleted the Uber App. In the alternative, he argues that he 
3  cannot be compelled to submit his claims to arbitration because the defendants named in this action 
4  were not parties to the terms and conditions contract. 
5  A.  Falls and Namisnak 
6  Generally, parties who have not assented to an arbitration agreement cannot be compelled 
to arbitrate under its terms. E.E.O.C. v. Waffle House, 534 U.S. 279, 293 (2002); Volt Info. Sci., 
7 
Inc. v. Bd. of Tr. of Leland Stanford Junior Univ., 489 U.S. 468, 478 (1989) (“the FAA does not 
8 
require parties to arbitrate when they have not agreed to do so”). Having never downloaded the 
9 
Uber App, Falls and Namisnak lacked notice of Uber’s terms and conditions, including its 
10 
embedded arbitration provision, and never manifested their intention to be bound.  
11 
Nevertheless, Uber argues that Falls and Namisnak are subject to the arbitration agreement 
12 
 a
 rtni as a matter of California substantive law. “[S]ubstantive federal law [governs] the enforceability of 
ouor 13 
Cif
t al arbitration agreements” but does not “purport[] to alter background principles of state contract law 
cC 14 
i
Distrct of  15  regarding the scope of agreements (including the question of who is bound by them).” Arthur 
s ri
tateDist 16  Anderson LLP v. Carlisle, 556 U.S. 624, 630 (2009). According to Uber, plaintiffs are precluded 
d Srn  from refusing to arbitrate by the doctrine of equitable estoppel, which permits enforcement of an 
ee 17 
th
Uniort arbitration agreement against a nonsignatory under certain circumstances. Id. at 631. In California, 
N 18 
“[w]hen a plaintiff brings a claim which relies on contract terms against a defendant, the plaintiff 
19 
may be equitably estopped from repudiating the arbitration clause contained in that agreement.” 
20 
JSM Tuscany, LLC v. Superior Court, 123 Cal. Rptr. 3d 429, 443 (Ct. App. 2011). “When that 
21 
plaintiff is suing on a contract—on the basis that, even though the plaintiff was not a party to the 
22 
contract, the plaintiff is nonetheless entitled to recover for its breach, the plaintiff should be 
23 
equitably estopped from repudiating the contract’s arbitration clause.” Id. When determining 
24 
whether equitable estoppel is appropriate, courts must look to the nature of the claims being 
25 
asserted to determine whether they are “intimately founded in and intertwined with the underlying 
26 
contract obligations.” Id. at 442-43. 
27 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
4 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 5 of 7
 
1  As Uber views it, plaintiffs’ standing to sue is based on allegations that they would have 
2  used the Uber App but for Uber’s discriminatory policies. Had Falls and Namisnak downloaded 
3  and used the Uber App, they would have been required to agree to Uber’s terms and conditions, 
4  including the arbitration provision. Therefore, Uber reasons, plaintiffs necessarily rely on the 
5  agreement in bringing this suit and should be equitably estopped from avoiding its obligations. 
6  This argument is unpersuasive. The fact that Uber’s terms and conditions are implicated in the 
7  averments of the complaint does not by itself indicate that plaintiffs are claiming some privilege or 
8  benefit derived from Uber’s terms and conditions, or that they are seeking to use the terms and 
9  conditions against Uber.  
10  The purpose of equitable estoppel is to prevent parties from invoking the terms of a 
11  contract as the basis for suit while avoiding a corresponding contractual obligation to arbitrate. 
12  Goldman v. KPMG LLP, 92 Cal. Rptr. 3d 534, 543-44 (Ct. App. 2009). “The linchpin for 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  equitable estoppel is equity—fairness,” and “the application of the doctrine is fact-specific.” Id. at 
Cif
t al
cC 14  555 (internal quotations omitted) (quoting Grigson v. Creative Artists, LLC, 210 F.3d 524, 528 
i
strof 
Dict  15  (5th Cir. 2000). Falls and Namisnak assert claims against Uber based on rights created by the 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  ADA, which are not dependent upon or bound up in the terms and obligations of Uber’s service 
d Srn 
ee 17  agreement. It is Uber’s alleged refusal to comply with the requirements of the ADA, not the 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  requirements of its consumer agreements, which form the basis of this lawsuit. See Goldman 92 
19  Cal. Rptr. 3d at 543 (holding that plaintiff signatories were not equitably estopped from refusing to 
20  arbitrate under the terms of an agreement because their “allegations depend solely on the actions 
21  of [defendant nonsignatories], not on the terms of the operating agreements, for their success.”). 
22  Therefore, it does not offend the principles of equity and fairness to conclude that Uber’s 
23  arbitration agreement is not binding upon Falls and Namisnak.  
24  Uber cannot use its consumer arbitration agreements so expansively as to block all 
25  prospective ADA plaintiffs from seeking relief in federal court. Because Falls and Namisnak never 
26  agreed to arbitrate claims against Uber and are not equitably estopped from refusing to do so, 
27  Uber’s motion to compel arbitration is denied as to their claims.  
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
5 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 6 of 7
 
1  B.  Miraglia 
2  Unlike Falls and Namisnak, Miraglia does not deny agreeing to Uber’s terms and conditions 
3  when he created an Uber account. Instead, Miraglia contends that he rescinded the agreement by 
4  deleting the Uber App, rendering the agreement’s arbitration clause unenforceable against him. In 
5  response, Uber argues that rescission is an issue of disputed fact that must itself be arbitrated, for 
6  “unless the challenge is to the arbitration clause itself, the issue of the contract’s validity is considered 
7  by the arbitrator in the first instance.” Buckeye Check Cashing, Inc. v. Cardegna, 546 U.S. 440, 445-46 
8  (2006). Because Miraglia asserts a challenge to the validity of his contract with Uber, not the validity 
9  of the specific arbitration provision contained therein, the question of rescission must go to arbitration. 
10  Alternatively, Miraglia claims that Uber Technologies, Inc. and Raiser, LLC cannot enforce 
11  the arbitration provision against him because they are not parties to the terms and conditions 
12  agreement. The agreement purports to create a contract between the Uber App user and “Uber USA, 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  LLC and its subsidiaries and affiliates (collectively ‘Uber’).” In California, “[a] corporation is an 
Cif
t al ‘affiliate’ of, or a corporation is ‘affiliated’ with, another specified corporation if it directly, or 
cC 14 
i
strof 
Dict  15  indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, is controlled by or is under common 
s ri
tateDist 16  control with the other specified corporation.” Cal. Corp. Code § 150.1 Uber explains that Uber 
d Srn  Technologies, Inc. is the parent company that controls Uber USA, LLC and Raiser, LLC. Thus, 
ee 17 
th
nirt Uber Technologies, Inc. and Raiser, LLC are affiliates of Uber USA, LLC, and parties to the 
Uo
N 18 
arbitration agreement embedded in Uber’s terms and conditions.  
19 
Miraglia asserts that defendants in this matter are not affiliated with Uber USA, LLC, 
20 
because that entity does not appear on Uber’s certification of interested entities. See Dkt. No. 12. 
21 
The Federal Rules, however, only require Uber to disclose a parent or controlling entity. See Fed. 
22 
R. Civ. Proc. 7.1. Because Uber Technologies, Inc. is the parent company, it was not required to 
23 
disclose Uber USA, LLC. The relevant local rules require disclosure of any entity which has “(i) a 
24 
financial interest of any kind in the subject matter in controversy or in a party to the proceeding; or 
25 
                                                 
26 
1 Uber’s consumer contracts contain a choice of law provision selecting California law. Barajas Decl. 
27  Exh. 1 § 7. 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
6 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 7 of 7
 
1  (ii) any other kind of interest that could be substantially affected by the outcome of the 
2  proceeding.” Civ. Loc. R. 3-15. Uber denies that Uber USA, LLC has a financial interest or any 
other kind of interest that might be affected by the outcome of this litigation, and Miraglia has 
3 
pointed to no evidence indicating otherwise. Therefore, the failure to list Uber USA, LLC on the 
4 
certification disclosure does not demonstrate that Uber USA, LLC, Uber Technologies, Inc., and 
5 
Raiser, LLC are not affiliates who are all parties to the arbitration agreement that binds Miraglia.  
6 
Not only is the arbitration agreement enforceable against Miraglia, his ADA dispute with 
7 
Uber is within the scope of the agreement. The 2016 terms and services arbitration agreement, 
8 
which was in effect when Miraglia created his Uber account, is drafted broadly to cover “any 
9 
dispute, claim or controversy arising out of or relating to these Terms or the breach, termination, 
10 
enforcement, interpretation or validity thereof or the use of the Services.” Barajas Decl. Exh. 1 § 6 
11 
(emphasis added). Miraglia’s ADA claim, which arises out of his inability to access and use 
12 
 a
 rtni Uber’s transportation services, is within the scope of the agreement. Accordingly, Uber’s motion 
ouor 13 
Cif to compel arbitration of Miraglia’s claims is granted. 
t al
cC 14 
i
strof  V. CONCLUSION 
Dict  15 
s ri For the aforementioned reasons, Uber’s motion to compel arbitration is granted as to 
et
tatDis 16 
d Srn  claims brought by Miraglia, and denied as to claims brought by Falls and Namisnak. 
ee 17 
th
nirt  
Uo
N 18 
IT IS SO ORDERED.
